Her husband is a professional waiter at a restaurant and he earns approximately 600 BAM per month. They generate additional income through cattle breeding and their poultry business. Senija is seeking this loan in the amount of 1,500 BAM in order to buy sheep to expand their business operations. With the loan proceeds, she hopes that they will be able to earn more money and improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase additional sheep to expand the business

loans.name: Maine Santa

texts.es:
Mrs. Mainebelongs to Villa Turistica of Catac II Communal Bank, she dedicates herself to the sale of food in her home in the district of Catac, province of Recuay, in the city of Ancash. With the loan of 1800 soles which will be repaid in 8 months, she will purchase: 4 sacks of rice, 3 sacks of sugar, 4 cans of oil, 2packates of noodles, 3 cans of milk, 1 packet of salt. She is 35 years old, she lives with her boyfriends, their 2 children, and both work and share the expenses of the home.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maine pertenece al Banco Comunal Villa Turística de Catac II, se dedica a la venta de comida en su domicilio del distrito Catac, provincia de Recuay, departamento de Ancash. Con el préstamo de S/. 1800 nuevos soles el cual será cancelado en 8 meses, comprará: 4 sacos, de arroz, 3 sacos de azúcar, 4 cajas de aceite, 2 paquetes de fideos, 3 cajas de leche, 1 paquete de sal. Ella tiene 35 años de edad, es conviviente, tiene 2 hijos, ambos trabajan y comparten los gastos de hogar.

loans.use: With the loan she will purchase supplies for the preparation of her foods.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add new dental care products and other goods to her inventory.

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Julio Cesar has been a taxi driver for 12 years. For the last two years he has also been selling beer in his house and in sporting events happening in his neighborhood. For this, he brings his tent, tables and chairs, and sells liquor at the regional championships.

Julio loans money on his own to third parties.

The loans which he has solicited have allowed him to buy the beer, and in turn, give loans to his acquaintances.

Julio Cesar would like to have a place to start a bar and liquor store.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer.

Julio César es mototaxista desde hace 12 años. Sin embargo, desde hace dos, él también se dedica a vender cerveza en su casa y en eventos deportivos realizados en su barrio. Para esto, él lleva su carpa, sillas y mesas, y empieza a vender licor en los campeonatos vecinales.

Asimismo, Julio César presta dinero a terceras personas.

Los préstamos que el ha solicitado le han servido para pagar la cerveza y, a su vez, dar préstamo a sus conocidos.

A Julio César le gustaría tener un local en donde montar un bar-licorería.

loans.use: To buy beer and loan money to his acquaintances

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia, a 28-year-old mother of two children aged eight and four, became a tomato seller in 2000. Working everyday from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m.,  she can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Sophia  now hopes for a loan to buy more tomatoes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes for her business.

loans.name: Kuña Rory Group

texts.es:
This group of the "Pacu Cua" neighborhood arose when some members of other committees that have repaid their previous loans decided to form another group. This is a very private group, due to the fact that the neighborhood in which they live is near to the International Bridge that joins Paraguay with Argentina. Because of this all the ladies sell merchandise on the border, as much on the Paraguayan side as the Argentine.

The merchandise that they sell includes various oils, flours, sugar, laundry detergent, noodles, clothes, lingerie, sheets, towels, cigarettes and plastic articles, because they adapt to the requests of their clients and also to the advantages in prices that they find. The majority have a small point of sale, other do not and offer their merchandise to people that pass on the street.

They desire a loan that can be additional capital for them, that will permit them to increase their stock of merchandise, buying in large quantities. One of the advantages that they get when buying in large quantities are the lowest prices. This also helps so that they can offer good prices to their clients, so their clients prefer to buy from them.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Este grupo del Barrio “Pacu Cua” surgió por medio de algunas integrantes de otros comités que han cancelado sus créditos anteriores y tenían interés en formar otro grupo. Este es un grupo muy particular, debido a que el Barrio en el que viven esta cerca del Puente Internacional que une a Paraguay con Argentina y por tal motivo todas las señoras venden mercaderías en la frontera, tanto lado paraguayo como argentino.

Las mercaderías que venden son muy variadas aceites, harinas, azúcar, jabón en polvo, fideos, ropas, lencerías, sábanas, tohallas, cigarrillos y artículos de plástico, porque ellas se adaptan a los pedidos de los clientes y también a las ventajas en precios que encuentren. La mayoría posee un pequeño puesto de venta, otras no y lo hacen paradas ofreciendo sus mercaderías a las personas que pasan.

Ellas desean un crédito que pueda ser un adicional de capital para ellas, que les permita incrementar su stock de mercaderías comprando en grandes cantidades. Una de las ventajas que obtienen al comprar en grandes cantidades son los precios más bajos, lo que también ayuda a que ellas puedan ofrecer buenos precios que haga que los clientes prefieran adquirir sus productos en venta.

loans.use: To buy oil, wine, laundry detergent, sugar, noodles, rice, flour, milk products,  clothes, lingerie, plastic articles, sheets and towels.

loans.name: Khursheda

texts.en:
Khursheda A. is a very hard-working woman and knows that each day she has to give her best effort and all her courage. She's married with 3 children. She works raising animals and feeding them with the goal of later selling them. This activity creates feelings of satisfaction in her  because it allows her to provide for a considerable amount of the household income. 

The care that she takes to feed the animals and supply them with occasional medical visits from the veterinarian has increased their numbers and so now she guides them into the field each day for feeding. She makes sure not to neglect her role as a mother, because she’s also very dedicated to lovingly raising her three children, who also help out in caring for the animals during their free time. 

Khursheda wants to improve her stable's stalls and produce milk in a quantity sufficient for selling it commercially. It is for this reason that she’s requesting a loan of 4000 Somoni (1175 USD) for the term of 12 months to buy calves and fodder for her animals. Please support this woman who is determined to change the course of her life through dedication and hard work.

loans.use: Purchasing calves in order to expand her business

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella B. is married and has five children. She has received schooling through junior high and now sells fried plantain and special kind of doughnut which is loved by many and it is popularly known as "Bofrot" at Bronibima near Elmina, which she has done since 2005. Her husband is a receptionist the University of Cape Coast. Stella uses her income to help pay for her children's school fees and other utility bills. Stella will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more maize, sugar and other ingredients to produce more food for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Stella plans to purchase cement and other building materials for the construction of their family's house.

loans.use: To buy more maize, sugar and other ingredients to produce more food

loans.name: Juana Nila

texts.es:
La señora Juana tiene 33 años de edad, es presidenta del Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia y vive en la calle Elías Aguirre 523, distrito de Moche, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Estudió Secretariado Ejecutivo, pero al casarse ya no continuó trabajando en la profesión, prefirió dedicarse a su casa. Tiene un hijo de 9 años y percibió que es necesario su apoyo económico, entonces instaló un negocio en su casa el cual consiste en la venta de comidas a base de pescado.
Con el primer crédito de S/. 300 que canceló en 4 cuotas, compró gaseosas para incrementar el negocio.
Con este crédito de S/. 1,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará gaseosa, servicio, banquitos e insumos para una comida que está programada de una institución.
Juana sueña con tener un gran restaurante con atención especializada.
texts.en:
Señora Juana is 33 years of age, is the president of the Grupo Solidario Santa Lucia, and lives on the Elías Aguirre 523 Street, district of Moche, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad, Perú.

She studied executive secretarial skills, but upon marriage she stopped working in that profession, preferring to stay home. She has a 9 year-old son and understood that her economic support is necessary so she started a business in her home that consists of selling food, mostly fish dishes. With the first loan of 300 soles that she repaid in 4 payments, she bought sodas to increase her business. With this loan of 1,000 Soles ($325) which she will repay in 4 payments, she will buy sodas, service, stools, and supplies for fare that is set up for an establishment. Juana dreams of having a grand restaurant with specialized service.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy sodas, service, stools and supplies to fill orders.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz tiene 26 años, es madre soltera, vive con sus padres y su pequeño hijo. Ella es administradora de una empresa de trasportes, y desde hace 4 años, también administra su propia bodega, gracias a ello puede ejercer su profesión y tener un negocio propio, debido a que las personas frecuentan su tienda para comprar lo boletos de viaje, también consumen los productos de la bodega de luz. Ella manifiesta que no tiene ninguna dificultad en su negocio. Según nos comenta, sólo tiene algunas dificultades cuando se retrasan los buses que salen de viaje. Este es su primer crédito con MFP. El dinero solicitado se invertirá en la compra de productos para surtir su bodega.
texts.en:
Luz is 26 years old. She is a single mother, living with her parents and her young child. She is an administrator in a transport company, and for the past 4 years has also run her own grocery store, thanks to which she is able to work for herself and own her own business: people come to her store to buy bus tickets as well as to buy products from her grocery. She says that there are no difficulties in her business. From what she tells us, there are only some difficulties when the buses are delayed. This is her first loan with MFP. She will use the loan to buy products to supply her grocery.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase merchandise in her grocery

loans.name: Zamaddin

texts.en: Zamaddin was born in 1972. He is is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town. He is settled in the Fuzuli region of Dilagarda village. He has been in this business for 6 years. He is married and has 2 children. Now he needs a loan of 950 AZN to buy clothes and shoes to resell.

loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes

loans.name: Maria Clemencia

texts.es: Maria Clemencia es soltera pero una mujer muy responsable y trabajadora.  Desde hace 10 años vende verduras en el mercado municipal, sus principales ventas son de tomate, cebollas, papas y zanahorias.  Necesitas su préstamo porque quiere vender mas productos como es fríjol, maíz y concentrado para animales, ya que sus clientes se lo piden.   En su casa con su familia también se dedica a la crianza de marranos.  Su sueño es tener un negocio más grande, y aumentar sus ganancias y ventas.
texts.en:
Maria Clemencia is a single, hard-working and very responsible woman. She has sold vegetables in the municipal market for the last 10 years. Her principal sales are of tomatoes, onions, potatoes and carrots.

She needs this loan to sell more products like beans, corn, and animal feed, as these are the products her customers request.

At her home, she also raises pigs with her family. Her dream is to have a bigger business, and to grow her earnings and sales.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her business selling vegetables and offer more products

loans.name: Genkey

texts.en:
A simple woman is Genkey Merkado, 39 years old, married and a resident of Tabuc Sur, Oroquieta City. She has 2 children. Her main source of income is fish retailing at Oroquieta City public market. Fortunately, she was able to acquire a stall in the public market which she considers a blessing, where she can display a variety of fish.

In order to have additional working capital, she joined Paglaum Cooperative in October 2000. She has had loans several times. Now, she is applying for PHP 5,000 to buy additional fish. She plans to purchase a fish car someday, for easy transport of fish to different areas.

loans.use: to buy additional  fish for re-sale

location.town: Oroquieta-Tabuc Sur, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occid

loans.name: Rani Nazir Hussain Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is a 39-year-old lady and a citizen of  Lahore, Pakistan for the last 22 years. Rani baji’s husband is N. H.. He manufactures car seats and sells them in the market to earn a profit. Rani baji is the mother of one son whose name is Waqas. He is involved in his father’s business. Rani baji operates a business selling bed sheets. She has been selling bed sheets for the last five years.  Rani baji is applying for a loan to buy leather for her husband’s car-seat-making business. 

Rani baji is the group leader for another six women from her locality. Shahida baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business. Misbah baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. Bushra baji and Rehana baji each want a loan to buy leather for their shoe-making business. Safia baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Razia baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy leather to make car seats

loans.name: Farooq

texts.en: Farooq is the son of G. Hider. He lives in Bagrami, Kabul, Afghnistan. He is 60 years old and a hard working farmer. There are 10 members in his family and he works with two of his sons to pay all of his family's living expenses. He would like to expand his business and purchase seeds and the needed tools for farming, so he has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani. He is glad that through the loan process all entrepreneurs have the opportunity to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds.

loans.name: Balla

texts.fr: Monsieur Balla G.  est un homme marié qui a l’âge de 35 ans. Il est marié et a un enfant, il habite au quartier Randoulène Nord de Thiès. Il fait le commerce de pièces détachées et est aussi réparateur de motos, il a son propre atelier  prés de la Lonase de Thiès  et réalise un bon chiffre d’affaire. Il a déjà bénéficié un prêt de 100 000 qu’il  a normalement remboursé et est son renouvellement  pour renforcer son activité. Il vend des croix, des bobines et des bugnons pour moto. Il réalise un bénéfice de 77 500f. Ce bénéfice lui permet de rembourser  son prêt et aussi  d’investir le reste dans son commerce.
texts.en:
Mr. Balla G. is a married man who is 35 years old. He has one child and lives in the Randoulène Nord district of Thiès. He does commerce in spare parts and also in repairing motorbikes. He has his own workshop near Lonase de Thiès and has good sales figures. He has had a loan of 100,000 francs that he repaid as expected and is now on his renewal for bolstering his business. He sells Croix parts, coils, and Bugnon parts for motorbikes. He’s earning a profit of 77,500 francs. This profit enables him to repay his loan and also to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his business

loans.name: Kodzo Mawunya

texts.fr: Monsieur D. kodjo est un célibataire qui réside le quartier d’adidogomé à Lomé, l’activité qu’il exerce et qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins est le commerce des matériaux d’électricité et divers. Il a démarré ce commerce en 2005. Il a déjà obtenu à WAGES un premier crédit qu’il a bien remboursé. Une partie de son stock est épuisée, il veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES son deuxième crédit pour se réapprovisionner en matériel électrique.
texts.en:
Mr. D. Kodjo is single and lives in the Adidogomé neighborhood in Lomé. His business, which permits him to support himself, is selling electrical items and sundry products. He started up the business in 2005. He has already had a first loan from WAGES which he reimbursed correctly. Part of his inventory is expended, so he wants to replace it and has asked WAGES for his second loan to replenish his stock of electrical material.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of electrical supplies for re-sale

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B. is from the village of Migcanaway, Tangub City. She is 32 years old. Gina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns & operates a fish selling business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from fishing and fish vending. Gina has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new fishing nets for fishing. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and to sustain her family's basic needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets for fishing

loans.name: Chhim

texts.en: M. Chhim, 29, produces artificial trees used for decorating holy Buddhist shrines, earning a daily income of $3.30 while her husband, a mechanic, is able to generate a daily gross of $26.60. M. is requesting a Kiva loan of $1200 to buy spare car parts for her husband’s business to enable him to make a profit when customers need to change their old spare parts. Because she wants to allow all of her children to pursue higher education at a good university when they are old enough for schooling, she has to save more money and establish a good business early.

loans.use: To buy spare car parts.

loans.name: Lucinda

texts.es: Lucinda tiene 52 años, vive con su esposo y sus 4 hijos menores en su casa propia. DesD. hace 15 años, junto a su esposo, se dedica a la fabricación D. faldas típicas D. su zona, a las cuales se les llama “falda mil rayas”. Lucinda implementó un espacio en su casa para su taller y una vez que acaban D. elaborar una gran cantidad D. faldas, como mínimo D. 50, las reparten ellos mismos a los comerciantes D. su zona D. los distintos puestos D. venta. Este trabajo requiere D. todo su tiempo y esfuerzo, pero en unión a su esposo e hijos pueden lograr superar su producción y sus ventas, lo que hace que sea una actividad rentable y puedan cubrir los gastos familiares. Lucinda ve el futuro D. su negocio con grandes expectativas D. éxito y quiere extenderse a otras localidades. Este es su octavo crédito con MFP, ella es una persona activa y perseverante que lucha por la unidad D. su banco comunal y se compromete nuevamente a seguir con esta actitud positiva. El dinero que viene solicitando será invertido en la compra D. telas e hilos en grandes cantidades para sus próximas producciones.
texts.en:
Lucinda is 52 years old and lives with her husband and 4 children in their own home. She has been engaged along with her husband for the last 15 years, in the manufacture of skirts typical of her region, which are called "thousand strips skirt ".

Lucinda implemented a space in her house for her work room. Once she produces at least 50 skirts, they go sell them to the merchants in the area. This work requires all her time and effort, but in union with her husband and children they have been able to achieve beyond their production and sales, making it a profitable business that helps to cover the household expenses.

Lucinda has high expectations for the future of the business; she wants to distribute her skirts in other areas. This is her 8th MFP loan. She is an active and persistent person who works hard for the unity of the community bank, and is committed to continue with this positive attituD.. She is asking for a loan that will be invested in the purchase of fabrics and yarns in large quantities for their upcoming productions.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kuanputun A1 Group

texts.en:
Kuanputun A1 Group is a group of 7 farmers in Bone Village, Nekamese Sub District – Kupang District of East Nusa Tenggara Province. Bone Village is situated about one and a half hours drive from Kupang City. Most of community living in Bone Village have a background as farmers who depend on agricultural products to support their family life. A  small number in the community depend on husbandry in meeting their family needs as it requires a large amount of capital.

This group is part of a larger group of 15 cattle farmers. Due to the recent devaluation of the Indonesian Rupiah, the group had to be split into 2 smaller groups to keep the loan size within the limit of $5,000 per group loan. Due to the remote location of the village, the partner was not able to re-visit the group for new pictures. The original photo has been split in half.

The community in Bone village usually consumes corn and cassava as their main food. They sell agricultural products such as bananas and coconuts at the market in the town of Inpres, which is situated about 37 km from Bone Village. The challenge for the community in this village is the availability of public transport to help them reach the market. The public transport only operates on Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and there is no local market available in this village so it is quite difficult for the community to sell their agricultural products.

Kuanputun A is led by a 34 year old farmer – Simson N.. Simson was born and grew up in Bone Village. He is a married man with 3 children; Dian N., 6 years old is in the first grade of Elementary School, Andhika N. is 3 years old and Alfian N. is 1 year old.

As a farmer, Simson spends his days cultivating the farm. He plants peanuts, cassavas, vegetables, coconuts and bananas. His family has always relied on the agricultural products to meet their daily needs. Simson’s wife also helps by selling their agricultural products but they generate only a small income, so Simson has difficulty to finance the children’s education fees and their daily needs.

Simson also faces the same difficulty as the rest of the community, the difficulty of selling their agricultural products inspite of the transportation problem. This difficulty has driven Simson to find another way to support his family life. 

Simson has chosen The Cattle Fattening program to increase his income to support his family life. Simson and his neighbors were really excited when they heard about the TLM cattle fattening program. Simson and his neighbors decided to form a group to receive a loan so they could buy a number of young cattle to be fattened. They are really interested in joining this program because the selling price of cattle is quite high in the market. They are sure that the profits that will be generated from this program will help them meet the familiies daily needs. They hope the loan will help them to improve their living standard and provide a bright future for their children.

loans.use: To buy cattle to be fattened

loans.name: Sokhea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhea Y., 45, and her husband, Mr. On Ork, 47, live along National Road Number five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 1985 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. One of them is married and lives in a separate house.
 
Sokhea has been growing rice since she was married. Her husband, Mr. On Ork has been selling cows and oxen. She is applying for her first loan of $1,000 in order to purchase a cart to connect with a motorized hand tiller to use for her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a cart to connect with motorized hand tiller to use for her farming business.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is twenty-eight years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, who are currently in school. Victoria sells utensils, men’s footwear and ladies' blouses. She buys her goods from the city center at affordable prices and sells them at the market square in her community. She treks to other markets to sell as well.

Victoria has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk. She aspires to expand her business and pay for her children to attend school up to higher levels

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk

loans.name: Chai

texts.en: The two persons shown in the picture over are Chai K. and her husband. Chai K. owns a store on which she sells a few grocery items to her neighbors and passer-by as well. She usually buys produce in bulk from a marker supplier to resell at gaining income. Normally, she can make average income of $3.50 per day. She has been running his business since early 2002. Her husband, Douk, age 23, who helps her with the business, and who is a local farmer. This young couple now has one young child who attends school. Chai K.'s investment is main source of income for the family and she recently sold all of the produce in her store. Therefore, she would like to ask for a loan to accumulate a larger number of groceries to resell.

loans.use: To accumulate a larger number of groceries to resell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has operated her general shop, selling household goods in Naivasha town, for the last one year. She is married to David Karanja and has four children. Her firstborn has already graduated from school while the other three are still school-going.

Elizabeth was introduced to KADET by her friend. This will be her second loan with which she plans to add more stock to her business. She paid off her first loan well, which she used in opening her shop. And with this new loan she plans to add more stock in her retails shop.

In the near future Elizabeth plans to own a bigger shop in a building that she will put up.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website:  www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more stock for her business

loans.name: Genie

texts.en:
This is Genie T., 56-year-old store owner from Tala, Caloocan City. She has four grown-up children. Her husband Roel, 59, is a government employee.

Genie has been in business for twelve years already. She manages her own sari-sari (general) store located at their house. On a daily basis, she makes more than P 1,000. She saves most of her profits in preparation for her husband’s retirement from work.

In 2005, she came to know the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and eventually became a member. She enjoys attending its weekly meetings for women entrepreneurs. Genie has applied for a new loan with the cooperative in the amount of P 24,000 as additional capital for her store.

Genie says she couldn’t ask for more because all her children are already independently working for themselves. She has all her time to attend to her husband and her store.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Norjinlham

texts.en:
Norjinlham A. is 29 years-old and lives with his wife and one-year-old daughter in Gobi-Altai province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife is a teacher at a local elementary school and his daughter is in kindergarten.

A. operates a cellphone selling and repair service in his town. He started his business in 2008 after completing a cellphone parts and repair training course. He has made a lot of progress with his business over the last year and has built a strong customer base.

A. has gained plenty of experience operating his business and continues to improve his phone repairing skills. The success of his business has raised his working capital from 500,000 tugrugs (~350 USD) when he started, to a level exceeding 1,200,000 tugrugs (~840 USD) today. A. hopes to expand his business in the future and dreams of one day owning his own repair shop. He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase cellphones and cellphone parts in order to increase his business sales.

loans.use: To purchase cellphones and cellphone parts in order to increase his business sales

loans.name: Alili

texts.en:
This is Alili M., a young entrepreneur from Tala, Caloocan City.  She is 31 years old.  Her husband works for a bus company.  They have two children living with them. 

Alili weaves foot-rugs by hand out of scrap fabric.  She also makes home-made sausages and sells them to her neighbors.  She makes a net income of at least 3,000 Philippine pesos (about $64 US) a month from these businesses which she has been enjoying doing for years.  

Since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative early this year, Alili has been enjoying its many benefits for its members who are mostly housewives.  She is now on her 3rd loan cycle with CCT.  She is expecting to receive a fresh loan of 8,000 pesos from the cooperative which she will use to purchase scrap fabric from nearby garment factories as raw material for her trendy foot-rugs.  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase scrap fabric for rug making

loans.name: El Progreso 1, 2, & 3 Group

texts.en:
Maria, 27, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, El Progreso (Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Maria, her husband, and their three children (ages five to twelve) live together with all of Maria’s extended family. They live in Batey Santa Lucia, a small community north of San Pedro. Bateyes are small rural communities built by sugar companies for their field workers. Bateyes are typically very hard to reach, have no potable water, and little to no electricity. Santa Lucia is a particularly small and isolated batey, but despite the difficulties, Maria makes the most out of her opportunities by selling clothing to her neighbors. Since the community is small and people need new clothing only so often, Maria will also use this loan to purchase food to cook meals for her friends and neighbors.

In sugarcane-based communities, during six months of the year there is little work to be done. This time is called “Tiempo Muerto”, or dead time. Maria says that it is during this time that she especially needs her business. Once “La Safra” (the harvest) starts, her family is not as desperate for income. She has smartly balanced her business around the growing season, taking out more money during Tiempo Muerto than during La Safra. With her smart business planning, Maria hopes to continue making profit to support her family and hopefully send her children to college. With your support she can do it, so thank you for lending!

loans.use: Rice, beans, plantains, and clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics products to sell

loans.name: Topacio Group

texts.es:
En la Asociación Comunal Topacio que pertenece al Centro Focal Panamericana, existe un integrante joven de 18 años, Harold B. que tiene el negocio de venta de celulares, inicio este negocio con la ayuda de su padre y su tío, al inicio solo ayudaba pero después su padre le dio un capital de arranque con el cual ha podido administrar su propio negocio, ahora quiere ampliar su mercado por lo que necesita comprar mercadería. Las demás integrantes de Topacio tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de masitas, juguetes, pan, comida, café, atención de salón de belleza.
Todas desean fortalecer sus negocios por lo que necesitan invertir en comprar mercadería, materia prima o activo fijo.
texts.en:
In the Topacio Communal Association, which is part of the "Centro Focal Panamericana, there is a young, 18-year-old member, Harold B. who has a business selling cell phones. He began this business with help from his father and uncle. In the beginning he just helped out but later his father gave him some start-up capital with which he has been able to start his own business. Now he wishes to expand his market so he needs to purchase merchandise. The other members of Topacio have their own businesses such as beauty salons, and sales of “masitas” (a type of pastry), toys, bread and coffee. All wish to strengthen their businesses so they need to invest in the purchase of merchandise, raw materials, or fixed assets.

Translated from Spanish by Mary McKee, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of Merchandise

loans.name: Olinda Del Carmen

texts.es: Olinda del Carmen T. D. F. D. 56 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Usulután, vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como comerciante. Olinda posee una venta D. frutas y verduras en un pequeño mercado D. Usulután. DesD. hace 2 años que ella cuenta con este negocio, el cual les ha permitido tener una vida llena D. todo lo básico necesario para sobrevivir. Olinda trabaja en conjunto con su esposo en el negocio, con la diferencia que el sale a las calles D. Usulután en un pick up ofreciendo su producto, y Olinda se queda en el lugar D. la venta, esto lo hace con el fin D. obtener mayores ganancias. Razón por la cual solicitan un préstamo, ya que Olinda desea poder comprar más frutas y verduras al por mayor con el fin D. poder comprar a menor precio y D. esta forma ofrecer su productos a menores precios que su competencia. Tanto Olinda como su esposo son un matrimonio muy trabajador, los cuales se esfuerzan por una vida mejor para ambos.
texts.en:
56-year old Olinda del Carmen T. D. F. lives in Usulután Department with her husband who is a businessman. Olinda owns a fruit and vegetable stand in the small Usulután market. She started the business two years ago, and it has allowed her to obtain the basic necessities in order to survive. Olinda and her husband work together in the business. He goes out into the streets in a pick-up to sell the produce, while she stays with the stall. This way they can earn the most money. They are asking for a loan as Olinda wants to be able to buy more fruit and vegetables at cheaper wholesale prices so she can sell her produce for less than the competition. Olinda and her husband are a hardworking couple who both put in a lot of effort to improve their lives.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy larger quantities of fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: Madeleine M. est âgée de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de Sainte ANNE1 depuis 8 ans. Avec son crédit elle développer une activité de vente de tissus et d'habits afin de réaliser des bénéfices qui lui permettront de participer à la prise en charge familiale.
texts.en:
Madeleine M. is a 48 year-old married mother of five. She has been a member of the Saint Anne Banc Villageois for eight years. She intends to use her loan to develop a profit-generating fabric and cloth business, which will enable her to play an active role in her family’s wellbeing.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her financial autonomy

loans.name: Makerita

texts.en:
Makerita  P. is 65 and married with 7 children (ages 20 - 42).  She owns a business venture, raising pigs for sale.  Makerita  has many years of experience in this business.  Makerita  needs a loan of WST $1000 to invest in expanding the business.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Makerita  joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Makerita 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Makerita  P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.87 out of 3
Level of Education:                         2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress.  The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation.  A higher number represents a higher score.  For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.  

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD:  http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sonunbubu's Group

texts.ru:
В нынешнее время, надеяться найти хорошую работу, или ожидать улучшения общего уровня жизни равносильно утопии. Единственное наиболее приемлемое решение для простых людей – это пытаться открыть своё дело и начать торговлю. Ормонбекова Сонунбубу – лидер данной группы. Она вместе с семьёй проживает в г. Карабалта. Сонунбубу пятьдесят пять лет. Муж Сонунбубу уже давно не работает и находится на пенсии. Сонунбубу с мужем вырастили троих детей. Они уже выдали две дочери замуж, а сын живёт с бабушкой и ухаживает за ней. Сонунбубу вовремя осознала свою ситуацию и десять назад начала своё дело. На часть своих сбережений она купила швейную машинку и начала предоставлять швейные услуги для местных жителей и параллельно начала шить постельное бельё на продажу. Её дело пошло в гору. За счёт получаемой прибыли, Сонунбубу смогла купить корову и бытовую технику для дома. Сейчас её чистая прибыль составляет около трёх тысяч сомов ($70). С этим бизнесом у Сонунбубу открылось второе дыхание. Она с большим рвением хочет дальше продолжать начатое дело. Но для этого ей сейчас требуется небольшая помощь. Она нуждается в кредите, который бы ей позволил купить сырьё и материалы для выполнения заказов на постельное бельё. В будущем Сонунбубу планирует купить новую швейную машинку, а также поставить новые ворота для дома. 

У Сонунбубу три партнёра по группе:

Даткаевой Багдагул сорок четыре. У неё трое детей. Чтобы прокормить семью она вместе с мужем предоставляют услуги евроремонта. Старший сын Багдагул уехал в Россию на заработки. Багдагул научилась делать штукатурку ещё в училище, и впоследствии эти навыки ей пригодились. Багдагул нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить стройматериалы для работы.

Исаковой Садие пятьдесят два года. Муж Садии работает водителем в военкомате. Садия же занимается разведением и продажей овец. Вместе они вырастили пятерых детей. Старшие сын и дочь уже семейные. Одна дочь работает в Бишкеке, а один сын работает в России. Самый младший сын учится в школе. Садии нужен кредит. Она хочет купить овец для разведения. 

Жунусовой Гулжан сорок шесть лет. Муж Гулжан занимается домашним хозяйством. У Гулжан пятеро детей. Две дочери уже учатся в университете, а остальные ходят в школу. Гулжан торгует продовольственными товарами. Она обратилась за кредитом, чтобы сделать закупку товара для расширения бизнеса. Её главная цель – дать хорошее образование детям.

--- WhereDidThisLoanComeFrom? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
In the current times, to hope to find a good job or expect an improvement in society’s quality of life is like expecting a utopia. The only more or less practical decision for ordinary people is to try to open their own business and start sales. Sonunbubu O. is the leader of this group. Together with her family, she lives in the town of Karabalta. Sonunbubu is fifty-five years old. Her husband is retired and has not worked for a long time. Together, they raised three children. They already married off two daughters, and the son lives with his grandmother and takes care of her. Sonunbubu realized her situation just in time and started her own business ten years ago. She used some of her savings to buy a sewing machine and began offering sewing services for local citizens. She also started sewing bedding for sale. Her business went uphill. Using the profits from this business, Sonunbubu was able to buy a cow and household appliances for home. Her current net profit is around three thousand som ($70). Sonunbubu got a second wind with this business. She strives to continue the business that she started, but needs some help with this now. She needs a loan to purchase supplies and materials in order to fulfill orders for bedding. Sonunbubu plans to buy a new sewing machine in the future and also wants to install new gates for her house. Sonunbubu has three partners in this group: Bagdagul D. is forty-three years old. She has three children. In order to support their family, Bagdagul and her husband offer European remodeling services. Their oldest son left to go work in Russia. Bagdagul learned how to make plaster while still in college, and this skills proved to be useful later. She needs a loan to buy building materials for work. Sadiya I. is fifty-two years old. Her husband works as a driver at the military base. Sadiya is involved in breeding and selling sheep. She and her husband raised five children together. The oldest son and daughter already have their own families. One of the daughters works in Bishkek, and a son works in Russia. The youngest son goes to school. Sadiya needs a loan to buy sheep for breeding. Guljan J. is forty-six years old. Her husband is involved in domestic work. Guljan has five children. Two daughters already attend a university, and the rest go to school. Guljan sells grocery products. She requested a loan in order to purchase goods for business expansion. Her main goal is to provide the children with good education.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies and materials needed to fulfill orders for bedding

loans.name: Silvia Mercedes

texts.es:
Silvia es socia del Banco Comunal San Benito.
Silvia es casada, tiene 41 años y 4 hijos, Silvia tiene un restaurante llamado Don Lucho en un local alquilado, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda D. 1 personal, además Silvia venD. bebidas al por mayor.
Silvia necesita un préstamo D. 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. azúcar, arroz.
Los sueños D. Silvia son mejorar su casa para alquilar e implementar una polleria.
texts.en:
Silvia is a member of the community bank San Benito.

Silvia is married, 41 years old, and has 4 children. Silvia has a restaurant called Don Lucho in a rented location. She works there everyday with the help of one employee. She also sells drinks wholesale.

Silvia needs a loan of $425 that she will use to buy sugar and rice.

Silvia's dreams are to improve her house in order to rent and to start a poultry shop.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar and rice.

loans.name: Cristo Y Nuestro Esfuerzo 3 Group

texts.en:
Maritza, 43, is a borrower who lives near L. Romana, Dominican Republic.  She is the coordinator for her group called Cristo y Nuestro Esfuerzo (Christ and Our Strength).  Her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Maritza is a single mother who lives with her two children in a simple home near L. Romana.  Their small rural community was built by sugar companies for their field workers.  Life is extremely difficult, with no potable running water, daily power outages and inadequate access to health care, among other dangers.  Despite these difficulties, Martiza runs a successful small business selling clothing in her community. With this loan, she will purchase undergarments, shoes, and pants to sell at a small markup.

This is Maritza’s second loan with Esperanza International.  She hopes to continue to grow her business.  Maritza is excited to continue investing in her business and family with the profits she earns.  Her profit will help her make household purchases like food and school supplies for her children.  Maritza is now confident that her children will have bright futures; a luxury she did not have before receiving access to business loans.
----------------------------------------
Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Maritza and the Cristo y Nuestro Esfuerzo group!

loans.use: Buy shoes, pants, and undergarments to resell.

loans.name: Chouk

texts.en: Chouk C., 43, is married and resides with his wife (shown  here) and three children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He is a motor-taxi driver and is able to earn about USD 3 a day. His wife prepares fabrics at home, earning an income of USD 1 a day to help cover the family expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a sewing machine and repair the house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new sewing machine and repair the house

loans.name: Akomakro Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Faustina is thirty-two years old. She is married and has given birth to four children who are between the ages of one and twelve years old. Three of them are currently in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the community. Her husband is an accountant by profession.

Faustina is a very hard-working woman. She is into trading. She trades in bags of charcoal. She supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. Charcoal is one of the most common sources of energy for cooking in most communities in the country. Faustina has been trading in the charcoal business for three years and aspires to expand her business. She is also hopeful to give all her children the best education she can afford. Faustina requests the loan to procure bags of charcoal in bulk.

She is the leader of a five-member trust bank group called ‘Akomakro’, literally meaning 'oneness in heart'. The group members are mainly into food production and trading activities. It is the dream of the members of this group to access this loan so as to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Marta Cahavela

texts.pt:
Marta chavela D. N. nasceu em Changalane, uma Localidade que dista 38km do Distrito da Namaacha, situado na Província de Maputo Tem 41 anos de idade é mãe de 3 filhos com idades compreendiD. entre os 6 aos 19 anos de idade.todos eles encontram se a estudar. Vive na casa própria com sua família e responsabiliza se pela sua mãe enviando lhe 1.000.00mt por mês.

Marta é proprietária de um trator inicia com trabalhos de lavoura nas machambas onde conseguiu juntar um fundo para dar início do seu negócio, anos depois houve um conflito entre familiares na disputa de bens do seu falecido sogro e ela fica na beira da falência. Numa conversa com sua prima que é nossa cliente fala lhe acerca dos nossos serviços e ela aproxima se solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt para reforçar o seu negocio. Ela consegue levar avante o negócio, tem viajado uma vez por mês devido a localização da sua loja que se encontra perto da fronteira e a maior parte dos consumidores fazem as compras na vizinha Suazilândia, ela tem como melhor produto (açúcar, arroz e bebiD.). Consegue de lucro um valor de 6.000.00mt e ainda poupa 1.500.00mt. Conta com ajuda do seu esposo que é criador e proprietário de 32 cabeças de gado bovino.


Este é o terceiro empréstimo de Marta na Hluvuku e segundo com Kiva. O primeiro de 10.000.00mt usou para reforçar o seu negócio pois encontrava se na beira da falência, O segundo de 20.000.00mt foi usado para aumentar o volume do seu stock e conseguiu com o empréstimo adquirir uma viatura que lhe facilita nos seus trabalhos diários. Este terceiro de 20.000.00mt pretende comprar produtos(acucar, arroz, farinha, bebiD. e outros)para aumentar a sua mercadoria. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo empréstimo para expandir mais ainda o seu negocio e vender a grosso.
texts.en:
Marta chavela D. N. was born in Changalane, a town about 38km from Namaacha, Maputo Province, Mozambique. She is 41 years old and has 3 children with ages between 6 and 19, all of them students. She lives with her own house with her family and also helps her mother by sending her U$90 every month. Marta owns a grocery store. In previous days she owned a tractor and worked in the farms where she was able to save some money to start her own business; later on there was some family dispute over her late father-in-law's properties, and she ended up declaring bankrupcy. She heard of Kiva from a cousin and she's asking for a U$600 loan, which she will use to improve her business. She travels once a month to get more products for her store, and her best selling products are sugar, rice and beverages. She makes about U$175 per month and she's been able to save U$40 every month. She counts with the help of her husband who own 32 cows. This is Marta's third loan and she's using it to buy more merchandise like sugar, rice, flour, beverages and others, so she can sell more and have more profit. She's confident she will be able to pay the loan back before the deadline, and ask for a new loan to expand even more her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products for reselling

loans.name: Leon

texts.es:
Nuestro socio pertenecen al banco comunal “LIDERES DEL TERCER MILENIO”; Nuestro socio vive en el distrito de Huanchac ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestro socio es ÉL Sr. León;  él tiene 56 años de edad, El socio es soltero y se dedica a la compra y venta de libros en el distrito de Santiago, Nuestro socio tiene un stand en la feria de este distrito y hay vende libros, revistas y obras literarias, el socio viaja casi frecuentemente a la ciudad de Lima, pero generalmente le traen a su kiosko sus proveedores.  Nuestro socio solicita el préstamo para comprar mayor número de libros y revistas.

El socio agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This borrower is one of the members of the Banco Comunal “Lideres del Tercer Milenio” (“Leaders of the Third Millenium” Communal Bank). He lives in Cusco, in the Huanchac neighborhood. His name is León. He is 56 years old, he is single and he sells books for a living in the Santiago district. He has a stand in the local fair of this same district, where he sells books, magazines and literary works. He travels very often to Lima, but it’s his suppliers who generally bring him the books. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy a higher number of books and magazines. He is thankful for and appreciates the help offered to him through this loan, and he commits to complying with repaying his debt within the specified time.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more books and magazines.

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.es:
Victor Manuel es un padre de familia de 48 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y a sus dos hijos en el distrito agrícola de Cayaltí, una zona que ha experimentado un creciente movimiento comercial en los ultimos años, se encuentra ubicada a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a trabajar desde hace mas de tres años fabricando puertas y mostradores de aluminio en un pequeño taller ubicado en el distrito donde vive. Este negocio cuenta con mucha acogida ya que en la zona hay pocos talleres de este tipo. Sus principales clientes son los comerciantes que necesitan de estos mostradores para exhibir sus productos y el público en general. Este negocio es su principal fuente de sustento con la que trabaja arduamente para sacar adelante a los suyos.

Victor Manuel desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de mas material como aluminio y vidrios con los cuales pueda aumentar su producción y percibir mayores ingresos, para lograr su objetivo ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

El es una persona bastante conocioda y respetada en la zona donde vive. Su mayor anhelo es brindarle a su familia la calidad de vida que se merecen.
texts.en:
Victor Manuel is a 48 year-old father. He lives with his wife and their two children in the agricultural district of Cayaltí, which is an area that has experienced a growing commercial movement in recent years. It is located one hour from the city of Chiclayo. Victor has worked for over three years making aluminum doors and counters in a small workshop located in the district where he lives. This business was well-received because there were few workshops of this type in the area. His principal customers are merchants who need counters to show their products, as well as the general public. This business is his main source of livelihood and he works hard to help his family get ahead. Victor Manuel hopes to develop his business by purchasing more materials like aluminum and glass, with which he will be able to augment his production and earn more income. In order to achieve his goal, he has requested a loan (of 2000 nuevos soles) from Edpyme Alternativa for the first time. He is a quite well-known and respected person in the area where he lives. His greatest dream is to provide his family with the quality of life they deserve.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy aluminum and glass to expand his door and counter-making business

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreymom C. (in the photo), 24, and her husband, Mr. Chamroeun Yong, 27, have been married for five years and have two children: one son and one daughter. The family lives in a suburb about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sreymom and her husband are garment factory workers. They also grow rice when they are free. The couple does not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain their rice farm. Therefore, Sreymom is applying for her first loan of $500 to help her capital.

loans.use: To use for growing rice.

loans.name: Mrs. Chi Mao Village Bank Group

texts.en:
These nineteen people, who live in Prey Prum village, TaK. province, make up this village bank loan group. Mrs. Chi M., who was born in 1947, is the village bank president having been selected by the other members. The members will each use their portion of the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Chi M. and her husband, Mr. Bam Sek, are farmers who own a half-hectare (1.25-acre) plot of land that they use to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Her husband is also a furniture maker.

Mrs. Chi M. has a problem because her field has infertile soil. So, to improve her rice production, she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. She is the mother of a child who is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing important materials for the wedding

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita G. is from the village of Banquero. She is 54 years old. Nenita is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Nenita raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Nenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Nenita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Amadu

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Amadu. He is married and has four children aged 2, 4, 8 and 13 years. He has one additional dependant who lives with him because she is his wife's elder mother. 
In 2001, Amadu established a used clothing business. He was financed by his elder brother to start the business as a means of improving his standard of living. Working seven days a week and eleven hours a day, he earns about 500,000 SLL every month from his business. 
Amadu would like a loan of 4,000,000 SLL in order to buy more stock and make more profit. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 250,000 SLL. In the future, Amadu plans to expand his business, build a house for his family, and continue to educate his children to university level. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Oyundelger

texts.en: Oyundelger G. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter attends university while her older son studies at the secondary school and her younger son attends a local kindergarten. Her husband works at Javhlant Bogd Co. Ltd. Oyundelger operates a leather goods manufacturing business. She has been engaged in this business since 1996 and since then, she has managed to expand her business by producing more types of products. Today, she produces a variety of products including leather gloves, key rings and holders, and slippers. She has been successful over the years and has built a stable operation. Oyundelger is hopeful for the future and is looking to expand the business. She is a responsible and hardworking person. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase leather materials and sewing machines for her business.

loans.use: To purchase leather materials and sewing machines

loans.name: Gulmairam's Group

texts.en:
Gulmairam O. is the leader of this group. She is 34 and married. She has three sons and a daughter. The sons are at school and the daughter is not yet. Gulmairam and her husband are farmers. They breed livestock. In order to make money Gulmairam sells about seven liters of milk per day. In this way she earns 2000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase five sheep for breeding. In the future she wants to provide her children with good education.

Dinara B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 36 and married. She has a daughter and a son. Both of them are at school. Dinara works as a nurse and her husband is a private driver. Dinara hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase cement and roofing slate for building a shed. 

Renat M. is 22. Four years ago with the initial investment of 20000 soms, he started to breed livestock.  He also provides transportation services to earn money. In this way he makes 2000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase ten sheep in order to increase his flock. 

Abdysalam M., 39, is married. He has two daughters and a son. The first son is at school and the others are not yet. Abdysalam is engaged in cattle breeding; he also grows wheat and maize. His wife sells 40 liter of milk every day, in this way she makes 8000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Abdysalam wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future he wants to purchase a flat in Bishkek.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Activas II”  ubicado en el distrito Juliaca, provincia San Román, departamento de Puno, tiene 25 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente y no tiene  hijos, tiene estudios de educación secundaria completa.

Martha es una socia nueva que solicitará un primer préstamo de S/. 500 nuevos solos al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, dinero que le servirá para incrementar el capital de su negocio de venta de verduras.
	
Su sueño es vender ropas en Juliaca. Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal  es la facilidad del préstamo.
texts.en:
Martha is a member of the communal bank "Mujeres Activas II" [Active Women II] located in the district of Juliaca, province of San Román, department of Puno. She is 25 years and is in a committed relationship with no children. She has successfully finished middle school. 

Martha is a new member who will seek her first loan of 500 nuevos soles from the Manuela Ramos movement, money which she will use to increase the capital in her business of fruits and vegetables sales. 

Her dream is to sell clothes in Juliaca. The thing she likes the most about her communal bank is the ability to obtain a loan.

loans.use: To increase capital in her produce business

loans.name: Verentino

texts.en: Verentino is a 30-year-old man, married with two children living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to educate his children, to complete his house and to have sustainable income for the family. Verentino has been a baker for three years and has seen noteworthy changes in his investments. For example, he has been able to buy a piece land amidst the challenge of fluctuating prices. Verentino needs the loan to purchase baking powder, sugar and flour for making bread.

loans.use: To purchase baking powder, sugar and flour for making bread.

loans.name: Jose Isrrael

texts.es:
José Israel, tiene 47 años de edad, reside en Jucuapa, departamento de Usulután, vive con su esposa, dos hijos de 15 y 18 años de edad, ellos dependen aun de sus ingresos, posee un taller de estructuras metálicas, este oficio lo sabía su padre y se lo enseño para que él también se dedicara a este negocio. 
Por el momento el tiene la necesidad de comprar hierro, soldador, alambre y platina por lo que solicita un préstamo para realizar estas compras, ya que estos materiales le son muy necesarios para realizar los trabajos a los clientes.
Sus aspiraciones son con el negocio que sea prospero, que tenga muchos clientes, con sus hijos pues que terminen sus estudios para que mejoren sus  condiciones de vida.
texts.en: José Israel is 47 years old, lives in Jucuapa in the department of Usulután. He lives with his wife and two children, who are 15 and 18 years old. They depend on him for his income. He has a workshop where he produces metallic structure. His father also pursued this profession and taught José so that he could also run the business. At the moment, he needs to buy iron, a soldering iron, wire, and platinum. As a result, he requests a loan to make these purchases, since these materials are necessary to do work for his clients. His dreams for his business are that it’s prosperous and has many clients. He also dreams that his children finish their studies so that they can improve the quality of their lives.

loans.use: To buy iron, a soldering iron, wire, and platinum

loans.name: María

texts.es:
María pertenece al banco comunal “Avanzando Juntas” de la ciudad de Talca. Ella tiene un puesto de  comida rápida, desde hace 9 años, ubicado en el patio delantero de su casa. Sus principales productos de venta son: hot dogs, churrascos, sopaipillas y empanadas. Atiende todos los días de la semana, de 17:30 hrs. a 1:00 hrs. 
Con este préstamo comprará cerámica para el suelo de su negocio, una batidora y también ingredientes para cocinar, como por ejemplo: harina, vienesas, mayonesa, pan, etc. Su sueño es ampliar el espacio de su negocio e incluir mesas para que sus clientes puedan comer en el mismo lugar. 
María es el único sustento económico de su hogar, ya que vive sola con su única hija de 12 años.
María está muy agradecida del apoyo económico que han sido para ella y su negocio, los préstamos de Fondo Esperanza. Además, participar en las reuniones junto a sus compañeros le ha ayudado anímicamente. 
Talca pertenece a la región del Maule, ubicada en la zona centro del país. La mayor parte de la población habita en el sector rural y se dedica principalmente a las actividades económicas propias del campo. Se caracteriza  por su hermosa artesanía y arquitectura colonial. Sus principales atracciones dicen relación con la producción vitivinícola.
texts.en:
María belongs to the “Avanzando Juntas” (Moving Forward Together) community bank in the city of Talca.  For the past nine years she has a fast-food stall located out the front of her house.  The main products she sells are: hot dogs, barbecued meat, 'sopaipillas' (fried pastries) and empanadas (stuffed pastries).  She serves in her business every day of the week from 5.30pm to 1.00am.

She will use this loan to buy tiles for the floor of her business, a mixer and also cooking ingredients such as flour, hot dogs, mayonnaise, bread, etc.  Her dream is to extend her business space and include tables so that her customers can eat there.

María provides the only economic support for her household since she lives alone with her  12 year-old daughter.  María is very grateful for the financial support that she has received through Fondo Esperanza's loans.  She also tells us that participating in her community bank meetings together with her fellow members has helped give her encouragement.

Talca is in Maule region, in the center of the country.  Most of its residents live in the rural area and mainly engage in farming activities.  Talca is noted for its beautiful handicrafts and colonial architecture.  Its main attractions are related to the area's wine production.

loans.use: To buy tiles and food

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a businesswoman who makes a living operating a retail shop. Her business has done well, and she has made good use of loans from Faulu Kenya to save money and hire one employee. Her goal is to provide her children with a quality education, and she has applied for this loan for 50,000 Kes to improve her productivity by buying a motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is a 40-year-old married who supports her family by operating a business of selling fruit. She lives in Aborlan, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $250. 

Nora is borrowing 10,000 PHP so that she can purchase a stock of fruits to sell. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 7,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Nora aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of fruits to sell

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry O. is a 27-year-old married man. His wife is a business lady and they have three children, ages 8 to 2 years old. Henry sells mangoes, oranges and other fruits. His business is located in Kakamega – a region in Kenya known for the production of sugarcane and commonly referred to as the sugar belt region. He has been in his business for the last three years. This business is profitable for him but his major challenge is the fact that fruits are seasonal. There are some seasons during the year when there is not much business due to unavailability of fruits. He also does not have a fridge, so some fruits rot leaving him with a loss. Nevertheless, he works very hard from early in the day to late evening to keep his business doing well. 

Henry is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy mangoes to expand his business and meet customer demand. He hopes to grow his business and stock vegetables, which he will be selling wholesale. He also hopes to purchase a plot of land and put up rental houses. Henry describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy mangoes

loans.name: Edwin Alejandro

texts.es:
Edwin, tiene 30 años de edad, reside en El Transito departamento de San Miguel, vive con su esposa y una hija de un año de edad, se dedica a una joyería, este trabajo lo aprendió de su padre, y trabaja desde hace 3 años, el negocio es propio  y lo atiende de 8:00am a 5:00pm.
Él por el momento necesita adquirir prendas de oro para abastecer su vitrina, solicita de un préstamo para realizar la compra, esta inversión le ayudara a comprar las prendas y ofrecer a los clientes variedad de estilos.
Ampliar la joyería es su sueño, contar con muchos clientes y estabilizar los ingresos a su familia para que vivan de una manera más cómoda.
texts.en:
Edwin is 30 years old.  He lives in El Transito, department of San Miguel with his wife and one-year old daughter.  He is a jeweler, a trade he learned from his father.  He has owned his business for 3 years and works from 8:00 AM until 5:00 PM.

For the moment, he needs to acquire gold items to stock his shop window and is requesting the loan to make this purchase.  This investment will help him buy the items and offer his customers a variety of styles.  His dream is to expand the business, have many customers, and stabilize income for his family so that they may live more comfortably.

loans.use: To buy gold jewelry.

loans.name: Juana Edeytrudes

texts.es: Juana tiene 50 años, su actividad es una pulpería  funcionando en si vivienda en donde ofrece productos de primera necesidad como son los granos básicos, ella atiende personalmente su negocio y siempre ha contado con el apoyo familiar. Actualmente ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de arroz, azúcar, detergentes, café, aceite entre otros. Su deseo es mantener esta actividad económica ya que en estos tiempos es muy difícil porque hay mucha competencia.
texts.en: Juana is 50 years old.  She has a general store that she operates from her house where she offers everyday consumer products such as staple grains.  She attends to the store herself, and has always counted on the support of her family.  Now she requests this loan for working capital, which she will use to buy rice, sugar, detergents, coffee, cooking oil, and other items.  She hopes to keep this business going, which in these times is difficult because there is a lot of competition.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Sope Serigne Bara Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPE SERIGNE BARA est créé le 15 août 2010, trois ans après l'inauguration  du Banc Villageois le 03 décembre 2007. Il est composé de 13 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même village. Elles se sont organisées par voisinage et affinité. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de B.

Madame DIARRA F. (la seule femme debout sur la photo) est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 28 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants en charge. 

Elle fait du petit commerce de pagnes tissés. Elle s'approvisionne à la capitale (Dakar) pour revendre dans le marché hebdomadaire qui se tient tous les lundis dans son village. 

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer son niveau d'approvisionnement afin d'accroitre ses revenus financiers

Les bénéfices générés par son petit commerce lui permettent de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille et à développer un petit élevage de volailles à domicile
texts.en:
The solidarity group Sope Serigne Bara was created on 15 august 2010, three years after the founging of the B. Banc Villageois. The group is made up of 13 womens who are all from the same village. They came together out of friendship and neighborliness.

Madame Diarra F. (the only woman standing up in the photo) is the president of the group. She is 28 years old. She is married and the monther of 4 children she cares for.

She sells handwoven fabric. She purchases her wares in the capital (Dakar) to resell them in the weekly market which happens each Monday in her village.

Her new loan will allow her to purchase more sstock in order to generate more revenues.

The profits generated by her business allowe her to contribute to her family's expenses and to start raising chickens in her yard.

loans.use: To buy a half-dozen handwoven bolts of fabric  and pay the transport costs associated with her business

loans.name: Sin's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sin was born in 1964. She and her husband are farmers who rent a one-hectare plot of land upon which they grow rice and bananas to sell. This couple is working hard on their farm to support their four children, three of whom are construction workers and the last, a student in the local school.

Mrs. Sin is the village’s bank president. She was selected to be the president by the other thirteen members of the group.
