texts.en: Kouadio A. is a 29 year old woman with two children. She lives in Abobo, a township north of Abidjan.  A. has been selling vegetables for many years and is good at her job. She got her first loan from AE&I in April 2005. She has performed very well in the repayment of all loans she has received from AE&I. She produces and sells palm bean in Abobo's open market. She is the main provider for her family. She is ambitious and a hard worker.

loans.use: Kouadio Amoin will use the loan to purchase goods.

loans.name: Mohammad Smail

texts.en: M. Smail lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is educated, and he is married. He has a son. His wife is a teacher. He was also in the Ministry of Education, but he was not satisfied with the salary, so he decided to start a business. He opened a retail shop. Now he needs capital, so he wants to take an individual loan to stock his retail shop and make a good business to support his family and make a good income. He is happy now.

loans.use: To fully stock all his materials

loans.name: Amen

texts.en: Mrs. Amen Asonrenemen operates a provision and drinks store. She lives in Benin City. She is 42 years old, married with 8 children. She started her business in the year 1992. She is soliciting a loan of $250 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale. She is one of the leaders of a group in LAPO.

loans.use: To buy more provisions & drinks

loans.name: Juan Alberto

texts.es:
John is a single man who owns a warehouse of construction materials. He sells bricks, cement, lime, wood, among other things. He also manufactures cement floors that are known to have good strength and good quality.

He worked for several years as an assistant in a warehouse where construction materials were sold, then the business owners, seeing his good work and dedicated effort, helped John set up his own warehouse.

Today, his business has progressed well and he already has two trucks loaded with transporting floors and brick. He wants the loan to buy sand and cement in large quantities, because they are the best selling products.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Juan es un hombre soltero, es dueño de un depósito de materiales de construcción. Vende ladrillos, cemento, cal, maderas, entre otras cosas, también fabrica pisos de cemento y que tienen bastante resistencia y buena calidad.

En principio el trabajo por varios años como ayudante en un depósito de materiales, luego sus jefes, viendo el buen trabajo y esfuerzo, lo ayudaron a montar su propio depósito.

Hoy día ha progresado bastante y ya posee dos camiones de carga con los que transporta pisos y ladrillos. Desea el préstamo para comprar arena y cemento en grandes cantidades ya que son los productos de mayor venta.

loans.use: Purchase of sand and cement. (compra de arena y cemento.)

loans.name: Mouhiba

texts.en: Mouhiba is a 52 year-old woman who lives with her family in the region of Nabatieh, in south Lebanon. Mouhiba makes bread, the kind that is called 'saj' in Lebanon. Mouhiba is a mother of 6 and is the only provider for her family. This is the second time Mouhiba is asking for a loan from A. Majmoua. She needs to buy the necessary provisions for her business.

loans.use: To buy the necessary provisions

loans.name: Thi Tinh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tinh, 50 years old, has 3 children that are working now. Her main activity is to sell rice. Besides, she also breeds pigs and chickens to increase her income. She has never borrowed money from any other agencies. She likes Binh Minh Microeconomic program because of its simple and convenient documentory process. She wants to borrow 150 USD to buy pig mash. With a daily income of 5 – 6.25 USD, she will be able to repay the money.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Cô Tính, 50 tuổi, có 3 con đều đã đi làm. Công việc tạo thu nhập chủ yếu của cô là buôn gạo, ngoài ra cô còn chăn nuôi lợn, gà để tăng thêm nguồn thu. Cô chưa từng vay vốn ở đâu, nhưng cô lại thích vay theo Chương trình Tài chính vi mô binhminhcdc vì thủ tục đơn giản, thuận tiện và cô đã vay 2006000đ để mua cám cho lợn ăn. Với thu nhập bình quân ngày là 80000-100000đ/ngày, cô có thể dễ dàng trả được nợ.

loans.use: buy pig mash

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tran Thi H., 29 years old, opened a clothing store five years ago. This is the main job of her family members. Her husband often helps her with the business. Selling clothes is a developing, popular job not only in Kim Dong province but also in others. Each month, her net income is 3000USD. "but this job requires a lot of liquidity", said H.. That's why Mrs. H. joined TYM Fund in 2006. After 2 years, she borrowed 1000USD from TYM. Now she would like to borrow 575USD to buy more inventories. This is winter so her winter clothes is in demand. Mrs. H. has two young children, one is 5 and one is 2.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị Hằng, 29 tuổi, mở cửa hàng kinh doanh quần áo cách đây được 5 năm. Đây là nghề chính của gia đình, chồng chị thường xuyên hỗ trợ vợ trong việc kinh doanh. Nghề kinh doanh hàng quần áo đang là một nghề rất phát triển không những tại Kim Động mà còn ở nhiều địa phương khác. Thu nhập một năm của gia đình chị Hằng sau khi trừ chi phí khoảng 3000USD. Chị Hằng tâm sự, với nghề này thì gia đình chị lúc nào cũng cần đến nguồn vốn vay. Do vậy, năm 2006 chị đã tham gia vào Quỹ Tình thương. Trong 2 năm qua chị đã vay tổng số vốn của Quỹ là 1000USD. Hiện nay, chị đang đề nghị Quỹ cho vay mức vốn 575USD để mua thêm hàng về bán. Thời điểm này đang có đợt rét đậm nên quần áo rét bán rất chạy. Chị Hằng đã có hai cháu nhỏ 5 và 2 tuổi.

loans.use: Buy clothes

loans.name: Jose

texts.es:
Jose is 48 years old. He has been earning a living transporting people in his vehicle for many years. Currently he lives in his brothers' house which is located by radial 17, between quinto and sexto anillo.

The transportation business is very arduous and requires a lot of time, patience and knowledge of the different areas of the city. Since Jose has a lot of experience in this business he knows the city very well. The competition in this business is significantly high; but the demand for the service is just as high, especially in Santa Cruz, which is one of the largest cities. Jose has his seniority in his favor, since he knows where are the strategic places to find clients.

The loan will be used to provide maintenance to his vehicle, to purchase tires, etc. There isn't a set fare for the transportation, it depends on the distance and the amount of passengers. Jose has a good credit history.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Jose de 48 años de edad trabaja como transportista de pasajeros desde hace muchos años atras, actualmente vive en la casa de sus hermanos que se encuentra ubicada por la radial 17 entre el quinto y sexto anillo. El rubro de transporte es muy arduo y requiere de mucho tiempo, paciencia y conocimiento de las áreas de la ciudad, Jose como tiene bastante experiencia en esta actividad conoce muy bien la ciudad. La competencia en este rubro es bastante elevada y competitiva, pero así también de elevada es la demanda por este servicio sobre tod en Snata Cruz que una de las ciudades más grandes, entonces Jose tiene a favor su antiguedad ya que sabe cuales son los lugares estrategicos para ubicar clientes. La presente solicitud es para el mantenimiento de su vehículo, compra de llantas y otros. No existe una tarifa especifica para el transporte ya que el mismo depende de la distancia y la cantidad de pasajeros. Jose tiene muy buenos antecedentes crediticios.

loans.use: To provide maintenance to his vehicle.

loans.name: Rosa Amelia

texts.es:
Rosa belongs to the Las Dalinas 2 communal bank, located in the Human Alana Sisley settlement, Block Ñ, Lot 5 in the Yarina Cocha district of the Ucayali province. She is 29 years old and has two children. With her first loan through the Manuela Ramos group of 300 Nuevo Sol (Peruvian currency) she decided to invest in a business to sell refreshments and popsicles in different places in the area. In the morning she prepares her products and in the afternoon she goes out to sell them. She enjoys what she does and has fun getting to know people who become her customers. With her business she is able to educate her young children who still need a great deal from her. With this loan of 800 Nuevo Sol ($300), which she will pay back in six months) she will purchase ingredients for her products, local fruit, sugar, lemon, barley, and ice. Rosa is both mother and father to her children and with this small business she is able, with a great deal of effort, to move forward in her life.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer Ann Kenney Molloy

La señora Rosa pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Dalinas 2, ubicado en el Asentamiento Human Alana Sisley Mz. Ñ Lt. 5, del Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 29 años es madre de 2 hijos. Rosa con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la venta de chupetes y refrescos. En la actualidad vende sus refrescos y chupetes en los diferentes grifos de la región, por las mañanas prepara sus productos y en las tardes sale a vender, le gusta lo que hace se divierte mucho y así conoce mas gente, y puede educar sus menores hijos que aun necesitan mucho de ella. Con este préstamo de S/. 800, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará: insumos para sus chupetes, bolitas, frutas de la región, azúcar, limón, cebada, hielo. Rosa es padre y madre para sus hijos y con el pequeño negocio que tiene esta sacándolos adelante con mucho esfuerzo y empeño.

loans.use: With this loan she will purchase ingredients to make her products

loans.name: Mujeres Luchadoras Group

texts.es:
This committee is made up of 18 hard-working women from the Santa Lucia neighborhood of the city of Caacupé. Most of the women own small general stores, while others own kiosks, sell clothing and chipas (a traditional Paraguayan food similar to bread). The group is currently on their third cycle of Fundacion Paraguaya's Entrepreneurial Women program; each woman currently receives an average of 943,000 guaranís (US$231).

The first committee meetings were held in the home of Mrs. Marilyn C.. 22 interested women showed up to the group's first meeting. Then, in the second group meeting, 18 women agreed to sign up and take on the benefits and the responsibilities inherent in the program. Today, they hold weekly meetings whenever possible. It is difficult to find a regular time when they are all free to meet, since most of them are ambulatory vendors and work very long hours, beginning very early in the morning and finishing very late at night.

Though this committee is one of the newest formed at the Caacupé office, the women are already doing all sorts of extra work in order to make contributions to their group savings account. This account is very important, and will be used if any of the committee members has to pay for emergency hospitalizations or medications, or to help women make their repayments so that they do not fall behind.

Each woman will invest her share of the loan to purchase merchandise or raw materials for the particular products she sells.

Translated by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva volunteer.

El comité está integrado por 18 señoras trabajadoras del barrio Santa Lucia de la ciudad de Caacupé, la mayoría de ellas poseen despensas, otras kioscos, ventas de ropa y ventas de chipa (comida típica del Paraguay).El grupo se encuentra actualmente en el 3er. Ciclo del programa Mujeres Emprededoras, y a la fecha todas manejan una línea de crédito promedio de Gs. 943.000 por cada integrante.

Las primeras reuniones del comité se realizaron en el domicilio de la señora Marilyn C. y en esa primera reunión estuvieron más de 22 personas interesadas, luego, ya en la segunda reunión, quedaron finalmente 18 señoras que aceptaron formar parte y adquirir los beneficios y responsabilidad que este programa ofrece. Hoy día ellas se reúnen en lo posible cada semana, buscando siempre un horario que a todas les quede mejor ya que la mayoría de ellas trabajan como vendedoras ambulantes y les resulta difícil disponer de un horario fijo entre semana ya que ellas empiezan su jornada de trabajo a muy tempranas horas de la mañana y terminan tarde por la noche.

Este comité es uno de los más nuevos que se formaron en la Oficina de Caacupé, ellas ya están realizando todo tipo de actividades extras para recaudar fondos para sus ahorros. Estos ahorros son muy importantes ya que los utilizan en caso de que alguna de las integrantes tenga una necesidad como la compra de medicamentos, internaciones, o también para pagar sus cuotas y no atrasarse con los pagos de sus créditos.

Los préstamos que recibirán ellas desean reinvertirlos en sus distintas actividades para la compra de mercaderías para la venta y materia prima para la elaboración de sus productos comestibles.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs such as starch, vegetable oil, cheese, sugar, yerba mate, milk, cookies, beef, soda, and other drinks, as well as clothing for women, men and children.

loans.name: Comité Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
In the city of Yaguarón, located 15 km away from one of our offices in the city of Paraguarí, women with the desire to start business activities got together in order to increase their capital and improve their families’ living conditions. These women got in touch with Fundación Paraguaya in order to get involved with the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras (Enterprising Women Committee) program. They gladly accepted the opportunity that the Fundación Paraguaya offered them, since no other institution had given them a chance to do so.

The committee is called “Kuña Guapa,” which means “Working Woman” in the Garran language. This group, which is currently in its third cycle with an excellent credit history, is comprised of 15 active and enterprising women. Their businesses include: general stores, fruit and vegetable sales, seamstresses, clothing sales, undergarment sales, handicrafts, soft drink sales, etc.

This group has received loans which are then invested in the women’s businesses as well as used for savings. In order for them to succeed with their investments, Fundación Paraguaya has provided training for the groups.

At this time, they would like to obtain a new loan which they will be able to invest in their different business activities, thus managing to yield greater profits from their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de Yaguarón, distante a 15 Km. de una de nuestras oficina ubicada en la ciudad de Paraguarí, se reunieron unas mujeres con ganas de emprender actividades productivas y otras para aumentar su capital de trabajo con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia. Estas mujeres se pusieron en contacto con la Fundación Paraguaya para interiorizarse sobre el programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, quienes aceptaron contentas la oportunidad que les ofrecía la Fundación, ya que ninguna otra institución lo ha hecho.

El comité lleva por nombre Kuña Guapa, que en el idioma garran significa Mujer Trabajadora, este grupo se encuentra actualmente en el tercer ciclo, con calificación excelente, integrada por 15 emprendedoras y activas mujeres. Entre las actividades que desarrollan se encuentran despensas, venta de frutas y verduras, costureras, venta de ropas, venta de lencerías, artesanas, venta de bebidas varias, etc.

Este grupo recibe créditos que lo invierten en sus negocios y mantiene un ahorro cada una. Para lograr el éxito de sus inversiones, La Fundación Paraguaya les proporciona de capacitaciones a los grupos de comité.

En esta ocasión ellas desean adquirir un nuevo crédito con el que podrán invertir en sus diferentes actividades y de este modo lograr mayores ingresos para sus negocios.

loans.use: Purchase goods such as meat, drinks, bread, cooking oil, noodles, rice, flour, dairy, saucepans, lingerie, clothing, bed sheets, fruits, vegetables, etc.

loans.name: "amanecer" Or "day Break" Group

texts.es:
The Amancecer or "day break" committee recently formed and is in their first cycle. The women live in an impoverished area, because of which the majority work in sales.

Of all of the women in the group we highlight the work of 60 year-old Serafina Zarcho. She is a single mother of 4 girls, which she raised with much effort and sacrifice. She comes from a large family and since she was a young girl has worked cleaning houses and washing clothes. When she was 16 she had her first child, and lived with the father for 7 years. Afterward she decided to separate from him because he treated her poorly, and Serafina took her daughter with her.

Then, as a woman, she learned to sew, knit, make clothes and sell them. She also taught her daughters these crafts and with them they were able to live. Currently, at 60 years of age, she cannot sew anymore because she suffers from arthritis. She decided to start a small snack-shop where she sells coals, sugar, herbs (for tea), flour, breads and other products.

Her greatest worry is the safety of her second daughter, Teodolina, who traveled to Argentina in search of a better job and left her three children under Serafina's care, as she has not heard from her in 6 months.

All of the women have different jobs, including food sales, clothing sales, make-up sales, cleaning products sales, pantry sales and traveling saleswomen.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

El comité AMANECER se conformo recientemente esta en su primer ciclo. Ellas viven en una zona humilde, por tal motivo la mayoría trabaja en venta casa por casa.

Entre todas las mujeres de grupo destacamos el trabajo de Serafina Zarcho de 60 años de edad, ella es madre soltera de 4 mujeres a quienes crió con mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio. Ella proviene de una familia muy numerosa y desde pequeña trabajó limpiando casas y lavando ropa. Alos 16 años tuvo su primera hija, vivió en pareja siete años y luego decidió alejarse de su pareja por los maltratos que sufría, llevando con ella la carga de la familia.

Entonces aprendió de una señora para quien trabaja a bordar, tejer, y coser a máquina, confeccionaba prendas y vendía. También enseño a sus hijas este oficio y así consiguieron sobrevivir. Actualmente con sus 60 años ya no puede coser ni siquiera a mano, sufre de una avanzada artritis. Decidió entonces poner un pequeño Copetín en su casa donde vende carbón, azúcar, yerba, harina, panes, y otros productos.

Su gran preocupación es su segunda hija, Teodolina, quien viajó a la Argentina en busca de mejor empleo y dejó a sus tres niños a cuidado de Serafina y no tiene noticias de su hija hace ya casi seis meses.

Todas las señoras poseen actividades diferentes entre ellas venta de comestibles, venta de ropas, venta de maquillajes, productos de limpieza, despensas y vendedoras ambulantes.

loans.use: To purchase clothing, lingerie, beauty products such as cream and perfume, meat, flour, sugar, fruits and vegetables in greater quantities.

loans.name: Mrs. Saom Sopheak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people in Toek Khlaing Village in Kandal Province are members of this loan group. All the members are married and have various uses for the loan which they will obtain. For instance, Mrs. Saom S., the Village Bank President, is requesting a loan to hire a labourer with oxen to plow her rice field. Her husband, Mr. Sok Sorphorn, owns a small grocery store in the local village and also helps his wife on the land. 

Mrs. Saom S. is 35 years old and the mother of two children who both attend school. 

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. All the members have end-of-term loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To hire a labourer with oxen to plow her rice field

loans.name: Kobbina

texts.en:
Kobbina T. sells jeans, T-shirts, men's shirts and other clothing at Kodadwen in Cape Coast. Kobbina has received Junior High level education. He is married and has 1 child. His wife is a businesswoman.

Kobbina has been selling men's clothing since 2003. He is responsible for helping his wife in the payment of utility bills and such. His loan will be used to buy more clothing (gents' wear) for re-sale. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to save towards a family house he wants to build with his wife.

loans.use: to buy more clothing (gents' wear) for re-sale

loans.name: Mercedes Del Carmen

texts.es:
Doña Mercedes P. P., tiene la edad de 44 años, su estado civil es acompañada, tiene un negocio que se encuentra ubicado en el Mercado Ernesto Fernández, en el sector de la Plazoleta de las Huerteras, ahí vende verdura (tomate, chiltoma, cebolla, plátano y guineo), anteriormente la señora trabaja en el campo con su esposo ayudando a sacar la cosecha de pepino, pipianes y yuca, al ver su situación económica y siendo madre de dos hijos, se empezó a preocupar más ya que ellos están en el colegio y por ende busco como iniciar un negocio extra para ayudar a su compañero, se indagó en el mercado con unas amigas y adquirió un tramo y con un préstamo que pidió de C$ 2,000.00 inicio vendiendo legumbres, solo tenía las ganas de que le fuera bien, un canastro y una mesa, hoy en día cuenta con 5 canastos y cinco taburetes ahora cosecha y el producto que saca lo vende en el mercado de Masaya.

Es necesario destacar que desde que Ceprodel le ha brindado crédito ha venido mejorando su situación económica ya que al incrementar y diversificar los productos han incrementado sus ventas. Actualmente su record crediticio es de 2 créditos desde hace 2 años
texts.en:
Mercedes P. P. is 44 years old and lives with her husband. She has a business that is located in the Ernesto Fernandéz Market, in the Plazoleta de las Huertas neighborhood. She sells vegetables there (tomatoes, chiltoma, plantains, and bananas). She used to work in the fields with her husband, helping him to cultivate cucumbers, squash, and cassava. She looked at her economic situation, being the mother of two children, and began to worry more because they are in high school. Therefore, she looked for a way to start an extra business to help her husband. She looked into the market with some friends and acquired a spot there. With a loan of C$2,000.00 she began selling vegetables. She just wanted for things to go well, with one basket and one table. Today she has five baskets and five tables. Now she harvests and then sells her product in the market of Masaya. It is necessary to point out the since Ceprodel has extended her credit, she has been improving her economic situation. Since she increased and diversified her products, she has increased her sales. Currently, her credit record is 2 loans in the last 2 years.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mrs. Mon N. is a 46-year-old farmer in Roung village in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.  Her husband, Mr. Toem Shear, is a cow breeder. One of their two children stays at home to do housework and the other attends the local school.  The soil in Mrs. Mon N.'s field is infertile and she has asked for a loan to purchase fertilizer and to hire laborers with two oxen to plow her field. She hopes thereby to increase her yield of rice.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and hire laborers with oxen

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea was born on April 8th, 1968, and he is married to Victorine Ijang. They are blessed with three children only one of whom is under 15 years of age. As a hard-working young man, he has faced some major challenges in life such as the death of his mother, poor health, dropping out of school and inadequate funds to continue his business. Because of all these challenges, Andrea later found GHAPE as a source of relief in 2005. In that same year, he received his fist loan of 20,000FRS, then 45,000FRS in the year 2006, and 100,000FRS in the 2008. With all these loans, his repayments were done promptly.

With the new loan, he plans to buy piglets for 100,000FRS, one month old chicks for 100,000FRS, and he will use his personal contribution of 50,000FRS to buy seedlings for gardening. Andrea will start repayment at the fourth month from the day of loan disbursement. He plans to use the profit from the loan to educate his children, expand on his business, and buy for the children’s needs. The business of Andrea will help his community by providing organic manure to them for crop cultivation and provide vegetables to the community. He is convinced the business will succeed because of the experience he has as far as the business is concerned, and he has a ready market to supply his product. 

Andrea prefers to take a loan from GHAPE because the method of repayment is good and comfortable for him, and proper follow-up is being done to ensure the loan is properly managed. 

---
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying piglets and seedlings for cultivation

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Roseline A. sells packaged pure water. She has a deep freezer that she uses to cool the water to sell. But the demand for her pure water has increased, so she needs another deep freezer to cool more pure water so that she will be able to meet the demands of her customers. She is requesting a loan amount of N70,000 to purchase one deep freezer. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase one deep freezer

loans.name: Nubia De Los Santos

texts.es:
La señora Nubia S. con mucho esfuerzo se dedica a laborar en su negocio de venta de agua, jugos y gaseosas teniendo su propio establecimiento en el Mercado la Terminal de la ciudad de León.

ES importante destacar que ella a pesar de su larga edad siempre está deseosa de continuar con su trabajo y ha buscado la manera de seguir adelante mejorando su situación económica. Para ello ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito con el cual compra las bebidas, gaseosas y el agua y de esta manera ofrecerlos en su negocio.
texts.en:
Nubia S. works very hard selling water, juice, and soft drinks. She has her own establishment in the La Terminal Market in the city of León. It is important to point out that, despite the fact that she is older, she wants to continue her work and has looked for a way to advance by improving her economic situation. For that, she has come to Ceprodel to get a loan so she can buy beverages, soft drinks, and water, and sell them at her business.

Translated from Spanish by Tara Binetti, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy drinks

loans.name: Nyanzi Chriatine Group

texts.en:
Christine is 24 years of age, and she is married with 2 children, ages 3 and 1 year. Her children are still too young to go to school. Ms. N. rents a single room with neither electricity nor water and they are four people staying in that room. She has one meal a day and the greatest expense for her in a month are food and medications for her family.

Christine sells charcoal to earn a living for herself , and she sells from home; she works six days a week. She receives about 20 customers a day and they can be men, women, and children. She sells on a retail basis. She has done this type business for three years now.

The main challenge she faces in her business is that at times they supply her with poor quality charcoal and her customers complain. The rainy season also affects the supply of charcoal since most suppliers don’t go to villages to collect the charcoal when it rains a lot because of the poor roads.

Christine has worked with MCDT for 2 years now and the reason why she chose to work with MCDT is because it serves the poor. She wants to use the loan she receives from MCDT to increase her stock. She also would like to expand on her business and be able to sell on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: increase her stock of charcoal

loans.name: Mary Joy

texts.en:
Mary Joy and Donald A. are a young couple who live in Barangay Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya with their three-year-old son named Owen Harley A.. The couple plans to have a small family. Considering their minimal income resources, they want to be able to meet the children's needs as they grow. The couple want to have a well developed and sustainable business to provide their children with a good education, so they will not be like them who, unfortunately, did not pursue their studies due to financial problems.

Mary Joy is trying her best to develop her barbecue vending business, while her husband works patiently in their inherited farm lot. Donald is sometimes hired as a carpenter in their village, especially when he is not busy with his farming. At their very young age, Mary Joy and Donald show their perseverance in succeeding for the welfare of their new family. With the income from her business, Mary Joy can help her husband provide a livelihood. 

They want to increase their income in order to build their own house in the future. Mary Joy is applying for a loan of $225 to be used in the improvement of her barbecue vending business, the savings to be put toward their house construction and the education of their children. They are very thankful that they found a microfinance organization that will help them reach their goals.

loans.use: Improvement of barbecue business

loans.name: Olusoji

texts.en: Olusoji A. is 36 years old and married with 4 children. He sells VCDs retail to his customers. He is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000  to purchase more  VCDs to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita B. is 49 and married to Danilo, a laborer. They have only one son who is a second-year student. She is a new member of Paglaum MPC, a Kiva partner. She took her first loan cycle last March 25, amounting to PHP 7,000, for additional capitalization of her store and to support the income of her husband. She said that she has to manage it well so that she can repay her loan on time and that she wanted to acquire a record of being a member in good standing.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her store

loans.name: Women In Need Group

texts.en:
This is Sallay C., Abie K. and Marie T.. They named their group Women In Need.  They are local entrepreneurs in the city of Makeni. This is the third time they’ve received a Kiva loan through SMT. Previous loans have made significant contributions to the well-being of these entrepreneurs. As a result of previous loans, their business expanded, their profit margin increased and consequently, their standards of living improved. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are now requesting a new loan. With this loan, they will be able to further strengthen their businesses.

Sallay C. (left) is the leader of the group. She is forty-eight years of age. She was born in Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a businessman and they have five children. Two of their children are already married, one is in college and two are in secondary school. Sallay sells food, including palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), rice, firewood, onions, oil, fish and so on.  She has been a businesswoman for more than fifteen years now.

loans.use: Invest in their businesses

loans.name: Jesna

texts.en: Mrs. Jesna D. is 44 years of age, married, and a resides in Baybay Triunfo, Ozamiz City. Her husband is presently enjoying his monthly pension, but still, this pension is not enough to support the daily needs of her family. She decided to open a Sari-sari Store to support her husband and children. She started this business with a capital of PHP 1,500 that she borrowed from one of her friends. She has now expanded into another type of business, which is the eatery business. She also owns and operates a motor cab for hire and is engaged in rice trading. She is applying for an amount of PHP 30,000 to add to the capital on her existing eatery, Sari-sari Store and rice trading businesses. Her future dream is to provide a better future for her children and she is planning to improve her business from an eatery to a restaurant.

loans.use: Additional capital for her Eatery, Sari-sari Store and rice trading businesses.

loans.name: Gulom

texts.en: Since 2004, K. Gulom has been a livestock farmer. He breeds calves, cows and sheep. He is married and has three children whom he needs to support and give a proper education. Gulom has improved his financial situation because his father is also a cattle breeder and, from childhood, Gulom has gained a rich experience in the livestock business. Nowadays, his biggest dream is to expand his business and to also offer animal derivates (such as dairy products) in the surroundings of his community. Therefore, his biggest need is to get a loan in order to buy more cows. Gulom is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to improve his living. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cows

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
N. Nguyễn Thị (122950784) is a 34-year-old female living in the town of Sóc Sơn. She is married and has two school-aged children.

N. owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over nine years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month.

In 1995, N. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business.

N. is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her 14th from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose U. is 42 years old and married with four children who are in school. Rose sells paint, using her profit to support her husband in taking care of the family. She is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more paint to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more paint to sell

loans.name: Fwazi Group

texts.en: Fwazi is the leader of the Fwazi Group. There are four members in this group. Each member wants a loan to expanding his/her business. They are requesting a group of loan 40000 Afghani. Fwazi wants a loan for her tailoring business. A. Fahim and Shbana each want a loan for their general stores. S. Hassam wants a loan for his taxi. They are very thankful to Kiva lenders who support all poor people.

loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Antofagasta Group

texts.es: En la zona Villa Tejada, se encuentra el centro focal que lleva el mismo nombre, a este pertenece la asociación “Antofagasta”, actualmente esta formado por once mujeres que trabajan junto a Pro Mujer hace seis años, demostrando ser un grupo alegre y unido. La mayoría de ellas están casadas y tienen niños pequeños, afirman que necesitan generar mayores ingresos para el bienestar de sus familias. Algunas de las socias venden abarrotes, comida, tienen tiendas de barrio, otras de ellas son artesanas, producen chompas tejidas en alpaca, creación de cotillones. Ellas precisan capital para la compra de materia prima o mercadería, ya que desean incrementar sus ventas de esta manera generar mayores ingresos para el bien de sus familias.

loans.use: COMPRA DE MATERIA PRIMA O MERCADERIA

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a fish vendor in their semi-urban village Linao East, Tuguegarao City. She is now in need of business capital and with this she would like to avail a loan of PHP5, 000 that she can use for the improvement and growth of her business.  She usually purchase fish in wholesale price then sells them in retail price in their vilalge.  She dreams of having a bigger house someday and support the needs of her children.  She believes that through her business, nothing is impossible. 

Marilyn is already 40 years old and a mother to two children.  Their eldest is 17 years old while her youngest is 14 years old. Her children are attending school, one in college and one in high school. Marilyn hopes that she can afford to send them to school until they finish their college education for them to achieve their dreams in life.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou R. is 51 years old and she owns a store where she sells mobile phones accessories. She lives and does business in Parola Compound, Binondo, Manila – a shanty town at the edge of the city coastlines. Her husband Menardo, age 48, repairs shoes and umbrellas for a living. Their two children are both in school. The eldest child is currently enrolled in college and the other child is in high school.

Marilou has been operating different businesses for more than two decades, but she opened her mobile phone store just four years age. She earns a net income of P16,000.00 a month. Much of her profits go to her children's education, while others are budgeted for their daily basic needs.

She is now studying the possibility of getting into new business ventures. She hopes that the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative will help her with her study. 

Marilou has applied for a new loan of P22,000, which she will use as additional capital for her mobile phones accessories business.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un cordonnier de profession. En 1994, il a ouvert son atelier de fabrication et de réparation de chaussure dans le quartier de Tokoin Forever à Lomé. Il est très expérimenté et a toujours su répondre aux désirs de sa clientèle. Beaucoup de personnes admirent son sens de créativité et d’adaptation. Il fabrique aussi des chaussures qu’il revend ensuite. Ses chaussures sont faites en peaux de cuir. C’est pour acheter tous les éléments nécessaires à la confection de chaussures qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES ; le prêt servira à acheter des peaux de cuir, de la colle, des doublures et divers éléments indispensables. Il est marié et a 02 enfants à sa charge.

loans.use: Achat de peaux de cuir, de la colle et doublures

loans.name: Neonita

texts.en:
Neonita L. has aggressively pursued her livelihood. She is a retailer and her business is what her family relies on for food, clothing and other basic needs. She is a fish vendor. She works early in the morning until late afternoon selling fish.

Now, she needs additional capital to keep going in her business. By buying more fish from fishermen, she will be able to earn a better income. The loan will have a big role in expanding her business and becoming a successful fish trader.

loans.use: To buy fish to resell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 30 years old. She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Christiana is a trader. She runs a grocery store by the roadside in her community. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase her inventory. Christiana desires to give her children the best  education she can afford.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Norma

texts.es: Norma C. es una mujer dinámica y perseverante, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa, región de Ucayali, tiene 32 años, es madre de cuatro hijos menores,  tiene una bodega en su casa y cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien es mototaxista. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Juntas hasta el final” desde hace cuatro años, donde siempre ha demostrado ser una socia puntual. El primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles que lo invirtió en artículos para su bodega. En la actualidad Norma necesita un crédito de 2000 soles que será utilizado para comprar productos comestibles e implementar su bodega. La meta de Norma es ampliar su tienda con una gran variedad de productos y tener una fuente de soda.
texts.en:
Norma C. is a dynamic and persistent woman. She lives in the city of Pucallaypa, in the region of Ucayali. She is 32 years old and is the mother of four dependent children. She has a small grocery store in her house and can count on the support of her husband, who is a motorcycle taxi driver. She has been a member of the “Juntas Hasta el Final” [Together until the End] communal bank for four years, where she has always demonstrated herself to be punctual. The first loan she received was for PEN 300.00, which she used to buy merchandise for her store. Norma now needs a loan of PEN 2,000.00, which she will use to buy food products for her store. Norma’s goal is to expand her store with a large variety of products and have a soda fountain.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products for her store.

loans.name: Alicia Sonia

texts.es:
La señora Alicia es socia del Banco Comunal “Tupac Amaru I” desde hace 14 años atrás del distrito y provincia de Yunguyo, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 23 años de edad, cuenta con estudios secundarios incompletos, es casada y tiene 2 hijos.
Alicia se dedica a la compra y venta de abarrotes y paralelamente a la venta de comida. Nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo incrementar su capital.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 3,000.00 nuevos soles con los que podrà comprar mercadería de abarrotes como fideos, azúcar, arroz, etc.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa en Tacna, comprarse un carro y que sus hijos sean profesionales. 
Lo que màs le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y las reuniones con las socias.
texts.en:
Alicia has been a member of the "Tupac Amaru I" communal bank for fourteen years, in the Yunguyo District and Province, Puno Department. She is 23 years old, has an incomplete secondary education, is married, and has two children. Alicia buys and sells groceries and, similarly, sells food. She tells us that with her first loan from Movimiento Manuela Ramos, which was S/. 300 nuevos soles, she was able to increase her capital. She requests a loan of S/. 3,000 nuevos soles, with which she will be able to buy grocery merchandise such as noodles, sugar, rice, etc. Her dream for the future is to have a house in Tacna, buy herself a car, and for her children to be professionals. What she most likes about her communal bank are the savings and the meetings with its members.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel McRoberts, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of noodles, sugar, rice

loans.name: José Antonio

texts.es:
En el municipio de San Rafael del Sur, el señor José P. se ha destacado por ser muy trabajador y él tiene su propio vehículo que funciona como acarreo llevando pasajeros del mercado municipal hasta cualquier lugar solicitado por el pasajero y cobrando una cantidad específica de acuerdo a la distancia recorrida.
La necesidad que atraviesa el señor  José P. es que le urge la reparación de su vehículo de trabajo porque está en malas condiciones y con el crédito que está solicitando logrará repararlo para continuar con su actividad de transporte en el municipio.
texts.en:
In the town of San Rafael del Sur, Mr. José P. stands out for being a hard worker. He has his own car and takes passengers from the city market to whatever location they request and charges them according to the distance travelled. Mr. José P. urgently needs to repair his vehicle as it is in bad shape. With the loan, he will repair the car and be able continue to offer transport service to the town.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repair

loans.name: Adriana

texts.en: Adriana is 23 years old, married and the mother of a baby who is breastfeeding. Adriana is very resourceful in providing her family with food and in paying the bills. She is a food vendor who sells rice and stew in her neighborhood. She has many customers who enjoy her hand prepared food. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials such as bags of rice, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to increase her savings to support her business and pay for her child's medical expenses. It was her dream to attain a higher education but unfortunately that dream could not be realized as she got pregnant and had to marry to survive. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials such as rice, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann O. is a married woman and the mother of four teenage children. To earn a living, she raises ducks to produce eggs for a profit. Additionally, she uses the excrement from her ducks to grow a few crops for extra income. She has a partner in her husband who assists with her in the business.

Vann O. will use her loan to buy more ducks as well as a piglet to raise.

loans.use: To buy more ducks as well as a piglet to raise

loans.name: Lagi

texts.en:
Lagi A. is 50 and married with 3 children (ages 16 - 24).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Lagi has many years of experience in this business.  Lagi needs a loan of WST $1750 to rent land to raise additional crops.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

You can view pictures of a typical plantation in Samoa, taken by a Kiva Fellow, at:http://picasaweb.google.com/agnes.p.chu/SamoanPlantation

In 2007, Lagi joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Lagi's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Lagi A. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                         1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2.2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to rent land to raise additional crops

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine D. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, phase and onions and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of onions to sell. Christine is 28 years old and is widowed. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of onions to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 27-year-old married man. He has been running a cafeteria for seven years.   Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has acquired management and customer care skills from the training they offered him and his business has grown tremendously.  He had previously taken out a loan of Kes 50,000 from Faulu Kenya, which he used to expand his business and successfully repaid. His dream is to own a restaurant and improve his living standards in the future.  He has requested a loan of Kes 60,000 to renovate his premises and buy ingredients such as maize flour and cooking fat and energy saving cookers for cooking.

loans.use: To renovate his business premise and buy maize flour, cooking fat and energy saving cookers

loans.name: Niño Jesus De Huaytara Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal Niño Jesús de Huaytara inicia su primer ciclo con 10 socias.
Las socias son del distrito de Huaytara, Provincia de Huancavelica, ellas realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de comida, golosinas, gaseosas, abarrotes entre otros.
Como es el caso de la Señora Estela que es madre soltera, tiene 3 hijos varones, todos están estudiando, Estela inicio vendiendo anticuchos en la calle, actividad que realizaba solo por las tardes, ahora también vende cebiches por las mañanas, Estela con el préstamo que obtendrá comprara sillas, mesas y vitrina.
Los sueños de Estela es educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales y tener un restaurante en un local estable. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 400 soles, 600 soles, 1000 soles haciendo un total de 7,800 soles.
texts.en:
The Niño Jesús de Huaytara (Baby Jesus of Huaytara) Community Bank took its first loan with 10 members who come from the district of Huaytara, province of Huancavelica. The members carry out different businesses such as selling food, snacks, soft drinks and groceries, among other items. Such is the case of Estela, who is a single mother with three sons, all in school. Estela started selling snacks in the street only in the afternoon, and now also sells ceviche (a popular regional dish made with fish and lime) in the mornings. With the loan, Estela plans to purchase tables, chairs and a display case. Estela's dreams are educate her sons so they become successful and to have a restaurant at a fixed location. The members will need different loan amounts such as 400, 600 and 1000 soles for a total of 7,800 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tables, chairs and a display case

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim is the wife of M. S. and lives in a city named Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. She owns a two-room house and has been living in it for the last ten years.

Shamim operates her own embroidered-clothes business. She receives orders from her neighbors and relatives and charges them 300 Pakistani rupees on each dress. She almost completes fifteen embroidered dresses every month and earns Pak Rs. 4,500 to 5,000. Her income allows her to share with her husband the financial burden of the family.

Shamim’s husband runs a grocery shop. His shop is located in the community where no other grocery shop is placed so his shop always fills with customers. Therefore, he has to keep additional stock all the time to earn more profit and to complete the orders of his customers.

Shamim has been taking loans from Asasah, a micro-finance institute in Pakistan, for the last two years. Now she is applying for her third loan to purchase products (rice, lentils, cooking oil and spices) in bulk to increase the profit of her husband’s grocery shop.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk for her husband's shop

loans.name: Jeanne Dohoué

texts.fr: H. Jeanne Dohoué est née le 08 Mars 1959 et vit depuis près de vingt ans au quartier Midombo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Jeanne Dohoué est mariée à DAMISSI Damien, un commerçant, et est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge, en plus de leur enfant. La famille vit ensemble à Midombo. Jeanne Dohoué vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Depuis une quinzaine d'année, Jeanne Dohoué mène comme activité, la vente de sacs de jute à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est aussi à Dantokpa que Jeanne Dohoué s'approvisionne. Jeanne Dohoué est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Jeanne Dohoué voudrait rehausser le niveau de son activité et acheter désormais ses produits en gros ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenu. C'est pour cette raison que Jeanne Dohoué sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un sixième prêt.
texts.en:
Jeanne Dohoué H. was born on March 8, 1959 and has lived for nearly twenty years in the neighborhood of Midombo in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Jeanne Dohoué is married to Damien Damissi, a trader, and is the mother of one child, who is currently in school. The couple has another child under their care, in addition to their own. The family lives together in Midombo. Jeanne Dohoué comes to the aid of her husband and, with him, provides for the family expenses. For fifteen years, Jeanne Dohoué has sold bags of jute in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. It is also in Dantokpa that Jeanne Dohoué buys her stock. Jeanne Dohoué is a veteran client of ALIDé, having already obtained five loans, which she has fully repaid. Jeanne Dohoué would like to take her business to the next level and to buy her products in bulk from now on. This will enable her to better satisfy her clientele and to encourage more returning customers. It is for this reason that Jeanne Dohoué comes before ALIDé to ask for her sixth loan.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bulk bags of jute

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. She raises pigs at home for an income of about USD 4 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike for her brother to commute to work in the town. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Leng N. is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kompong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. She and her husband buy and sell rubber for an income of USD 7.90 per day. N. also sells Cambodian noodles at home to generate extra income for the family.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to buy more rubber to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more rubber to sell

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida D. is from the town of Santa Josefa. She is 52 years old, married and has 6 children. Her oldest child is now aged 31 and she still has children who go to school. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over 17 years.

Zenaida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Zenaida from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees and to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Ky

texts.en:
Mrs. Ky K., 49 years old, is a villager in Chuos village in Takeo province. To support her family she is a cake maker. Her husband, Mr. Hien Ben, is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family.

Although they try to work hard they earn only a little money. To improve their family's living, Mrs. Ky K. is seeking a loan to buy five piglets and pig food for breeding. With the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer and rent a plow to plow her husband’s field.

They have four children. Two are seamstresses in a garment factory and the other two are laborers in Thailand.

loans.use: To buy five piglets and pig food.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.en:
Rolando M. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 37 years old and single. To make a living, Rolando owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food & daily use products and soft-drinks of various brands in the local community. Rolando has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Rolando joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolando is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rolando from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Dative

texts.en:
Dative is 42 years old and has 8 children who range from 6-24 years of age. Four of her children are in school, while the other children are not in school because she can’t afford to pay their school fees.  Her husband is handicapped, yet he still practices farming.  

Dative sells foodstuffs such as sorghum.  She keeps these food items in large sacks in her store to create space for more items.  She has done this business for 16 years.  She wants a loan to buy more sorghum to add to her inventory.  With a greater inventory she believes she will be able to sell larger amounts and generate more income.

loans.use: Purchasing sorghum for sale

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie B. is from the village of San Juan. She is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Josie owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Josie has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI with that loan used to pay for services to increase her crop yield. Josie is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the third loan that Josie has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Maria Esperanza

texts.es:
Maria Esperanza tiene 25 años de edad y vive junto a su familia en el distrito de Pacasmayo, un distrito situado cerca al mar que tiene como actividades principales a la pesca y al comercio. Pertenece a la provincia del mismo nombre y se encuentra ubicada en la región La Libertad, aproximadamente a dos horas de distancia de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica a la venta de F. en el exterior del mercado de la ciudad de Pacasmayo, ella realiza esta actividad todos los dias y ya tiene varios años de experiencia en el rubro. Sus clientes prefieren su negocio debido a la calidad de trato y a la variedad de F. que ofrece. Los ingresos que percibe de este negocio los utiliza para apoyar a su familia con su economia diaria.

María desea implementar su negocio con la compra de mas F., de modo que pueda ampliar sus ventas y percibir un mayor numero de ganancias, para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de soicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

Ella es una mujer respnsable y bastante entregada a su trabajo. En la zona donde vive las personas que le conocen le tienen mucha estima y aprecio. Anteriormente ya ha tenido créditos con Edpyme Alternativa y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Maria Esperanza is 25 years old. She lives with her family in the Pacasmayo district, a district located close to the ocean, whose main activies are fishing and trade. It belongs to the province of the same name and is in the La Libertad region. It is approximately two hours from the city Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region. She sells flowers outside the Pacasmayo city market. She does this activity every day and has several years experience in this area. Her customers prefer her business due to the quality of service and the variety of flowers she offers. She uses the income she receives from this business to support her family's daily expenses. Maria wants to outfit her business by purchasing more flowers so that she can increase her sales and earn more profit. To acheive her goal, it has been necessary to ask Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 1500 nuevos soles. She is a responsible woman who is very dedicated to her job. In the area where she lives, people know her and esteem and appreciate her. She has already had loans with Edpyme Alternativa previously and she has shown herself to be punctual and responsible when making her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase flowers to grow her business in the market.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita V. is from the village of Brgy. Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 55 years old. Teresita is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a taxi driver, husband and father of four sons and two daughters.  Hasan has been a taxi driver for seven years now, and his car needs urgent maintenance, so he took a $3000 loan for the maintenance.

The overall maintenance Hasan wants for the car will reduce the almost weekly expenses of fixing the car.  Hasan is also saving money so that one day he can have his own small taxi company.

Hasan appears in the picture here next to his car.

loans.use: Car maintenance

loans.name: Diosdado

texts.en:
Diosdado A. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 38 years old. Diosdado is married and has a 10-year-old child. To make a living, Diosdado owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Diosdado has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Diosdado joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Diosdado is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family financially.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Haytham

texts.ar:
هيثم عمره 38 سنة غير متزوج يعمل في تعهدات الدهان واعمال الصيانة يعمل منذ اكثر من 12 سنة يحب ان يبني اسرة , له في مجال عمله خبرة واسعة لكن ما ينقصه
هو المادة لكي ينمو بعمله يحب عمله جدا له زبائن كثر من محيطه وجيرانه عمله جيد يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة شراء ارض له في البقاع لتعميرها وزيادة 
مدخوله مصلحته خاصة به لديه صعوبة في محيطه العملي من خلال المنافسة
texts.en: Haytham is 38 years old. He is single, and for more than 12 years, he has been involved in paint and maintenance works. Haytham would like to start a family. He possesses the necessary expertise to thrive but is financially challenged.  Haytham loves his job and has his own clientele, which includes his neighbors. He would like to request a loan from A. Majmoua to purchase a piece of land and develop it, thereby increasing his business income. Haytham is also challenged by competition within the field.

loans.use: Purchasing a piece of land in his hometown of Bekaa

loans.name: Juana Francisca

texts.es:
Doña Juana, tiene 57 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de tortillas, reside en San Miguel, vive con su esposo y su hijo de 40 años de edad, este negocio fue fundado por iniciativa propia desde hace 6 años, los clientes los conforman sus amigos y vecinos cercanos, su esposo la apoya en todo momento.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para la compra de maíz y leña, pues se le han agotado y es de vital importancia que no le falten ya que son el principal elemento para la preparación de las tortillas, con este préstamo ella estará aumentando su inventario y podrá crecer la producción de las tortillas.
Su objetivo es mantener el negocio estable, seguir trabajando mientras tenga salud, para ayudar con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Doña Juana, 57 years of age, is dedicated to the sale of tortillas.  She lives in San Miguel with her husband and their 40 year-old son.  This business was started 6 years ago on her own initiative.  Her clients are friends and neighbors.  Her husband supports her in everything. 
At this time she requests a loan to buy corn and firewood, because her supply has been exhausted.  It is of vital importance that she not lack for these supplies since they are the main element for the preparation of the tortillas.  With this loan she will grow her inventory and be able to increase production of the tortillas.  
Her objective is to maintain the stable business, to continue working while health permits and to help with the expenses of the home.

loans.use: to buy corn and firewood

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married man with six children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over twelve years, he has operated a fish selling business at the market. In addition he has rental houses which contribute to his income. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes to establish a butcher shop in the future.

With the Kshs 25,000, he wants to purchase two ice boxes to preserve fresh fish for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase 2 ice boxes to preserve fresh fish for sale

loans.name: Madres Unidas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se formó a través de la Sra. Beata, les invito a sus vecinas para conformar un comité. Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas, crías de animales, etc. 
Las integrantes formaron un grupo muy unido y capaz de realizar conjuntamente actividades que fortalecen su compañerismo. Este comité ya están en su tercer ciclo, todo este tiempo demostraron puntualidad, solidaridad y  unión entres las compañeras.
Una de la integrantes es la señora Gregoria F. quien se dedica a la cría y venta de animales menores como gallinas, patos, cerdos y otros.
Ella los crías y en el momento de alguna de necesidad que tiene la familia vende sus animales para contar con los medios económicos que necesitan.
Se encuentra muy contenta con el grupo y solicita el préstamo para la compra de tejidos ya que desea construir porquerizas y gallineros con mejores instalaciones para sus animales.
texts.en:
This Group was founded by Ms. Beata who invited her neighbors to form a committee.  All of the members of the committee are engaged in independent businesses such as sales, raising animals, etc.  The members are a very united group who participate in joint activities that strengthen their camaraderie.  This committee is already in their third loan cycle and, throughout this time, they have shown punctuality, solidarity, and union among the partners.

One of the members is Ms. Gregoria F. who raises and sells small animals such as chickens, ducks, pigs, and others.  When the need arises, she sells them in order to raise money to support her family.  She is very happy with the group and is requesting this loan to buy material as she wishes to build pigpens and henhouses with better accommodations for her animals.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Merriam

texts.en:
Merriam P. is from the village of Bacnor East, Burgos, Isabela. She is 54 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, Merriam owns a general store which she has had for over 17 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Merriam joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merriam has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Merriam is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Merriam from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated  to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Devaki

texts.en:
This is 38 year-old Devaki K..  She is married and has 2 children aged 16 and 14.  In 2005, she established  her grocery store business.  Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supoorts her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buys grocery goods for her shop.  

In the future, Devaki plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support.  

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
 BPW Partner Page     Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.use: to buys grocery goods for her shop

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 39 year-old married man living in Tripoli.  He has 6 children. Since 2000, Ibrahim has sold coffee to customers including his friends, relatives, neighbors and foreigners.  He works hard to provide a secure living for his family members. 

To increase his family's income, Ibrahim is planning to buy a bus in order to start a new business.  Ibrahim is requesting this loan from Al Majmoua to  improve his social and financial situation, and he hopes to attain his goals.

loans.use: To buy a bus and start a new business

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey A., born in 1968, lives in Kokir Thum village in Kandal Province, where she owns a plot of land upon which she grows rice.
